{{other people|David Abraham}} {{Infobox person | name = David Abraham | image = <!-- just the name, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1963}} | birth_place = [[Lincoln, Lincolnshire]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|Month DD, YYYY|Month DD, YYYY}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | known_for = | title = ex-Chief Executive of [[Channel Four Television Corporation]] | term = 2010 - October 2017 | predecessor = [[Andy Duncan (executive)|Andy Duncan]] | successor = [[Alex Mahon]] | salary = [[British pound|£]]490,000 (April 2010) }} '''David Abraham''' (born August 1963) is a British media executive, who is the ex-chief executive of [[Channel Four Television Corporation|Channel 4 Television Corporation]].<ref>{{cite news|url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/david-abraham-interview-my-baby-the-sexy-love-child-of-stephen-hawking-and-steve-jobs-9864215.html|title = David Abraham interview: My baby, the sexy love child of Stephen|website = The Independent|language = en-GB|access-date = 2016-04-11}}</ref> In 1997 he co-founded the creative agency St. Luke’s. Abraham then went on to senior creative roles at [[Discovery Communications]] in the UK and the US before becoming CEO of [[UKTV]] in 2007 and then CEO of [[Channel 4]] from 2010 to 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://howdidtheydoit.net/business-2/david-abraham-ceo-channel-4/|title = Interview: David Abraham: CEO, Channel 4|website = How Did They Do It?|language = en-US|access-date = 2016-04-11}}</ref>
== Early life == Abraham was born in [[Lincolnshire]]. Both his parents immigrated to the UK in the 1950s – his mother from Belgium and his father from [[Calcutta]]. He moved with his parents and sister to [[Essex]] in the 1970s where he attended local state schools, before going to [[University of Oxford|Oxford University]] in 1981 to study Modern History at [[Magdalen College, Oxford|Magdalen College]].
==Early career==
Abraham began his working life at the advertising agency [[Benton & Bowles]] in London in 1984. He moved to the creative agency [[Collett Dickenson Pearce|Collett Dickenson Peace]] (CDP) and worked with [[Indra Sinha]] and Neil Godfrey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/cdp-duo-sinha-godfrey-reunite-c4-ad/1162343|title=CDP duo Sinha and Godfrey reunite for C4 ad|website=www.campaignlive.co.uk|access-date=2016-04-11}}</ref> In 1990 he moved to the London office of the Californian creative agency Chiat/Day – launched by MT Rainey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://businessshapers.co.uk/shaper-mt-rainey/|title=Shaper: MT Rainey - Business Shapers|website=Business Shapers|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-04-11}}</ref>
=== St Luke’s === In 1995, [[Jay Chiat]] sold his agency network to [[Omnicom Group|Omnicom]] with the intention to globally merge Chiat/Day with [[TBWA Worldwide|TBWA]]. In the UK, client conflicts prompted an employee buy-out of the business, led by Andy Law and Abraham,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/me-and-my-partner-andy-law-and-david-abraham-1072895.html|title=Me And My Partner: Andy Law and David Abraham|website=The Independent|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-04-11}}</ref> who became Chief Operating Officer. St. Luke's has been featured in Law's book Open Minds, in the Harvard Business Review<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hbr.org/2000/09/creating-the-most-frightening-company-on-earth|title=Creating the Most Frightening Company on Earth|website=Harvard Business Review|access-date=2016-04-11}}</ref> and in a Channel 4 [[Cutting Edge (TV series)|Cutting Edge]] Documentary.
=== Discovery Networks Europe === Abraham became the general manager of Discovery Networks Europe in 2001.
=== TLC US === Abraham became general manager of [[TLC (TV network)|TLC]] in 2005,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/discoverys-abraham-joins-tlc/1019926.article|title=Discovery's Abraham joins TLC|website=www.broadcastnow.co.uk|access-date=2016-04-14}}</ref> a US cable channel available in over 90m US households.
=== UKTV === In 2007, Abraham became the chief executive of [[UKTV]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://corporate.uktv.co.uk/about-uktv/article/uktv-company-timeline|title=UKTV Company Timeline {{!}} About UKTV {{!}} UKTV Corporate Site|website=corporate.uktv.co.uk|access-date=2016-04-11}}</ref> At the time UKTV was a joint venture between [[BBC Worldwide]] and [[Virgin Media]]. During his tenure, he oversaw launches of [[Dave (TV channel)|Dave]], [[Alibi (TV channel)|Alibi]], [[Watch (TV Channel)|Watch]], [[Yesterday (TV channel)|Yesterday]] and [[Really (TV channel)|Really]].
==Channel Four== Abraham succeeded interim chief executive [[Anne Bulford]] in May 2010 following a period of relative uncertainty at [[Channel 4]] involving a debate about the organisation's self-sufficiency, leading to what was described as a 'public begging bowl' strategy. Abraham was appointed by incoming chairman [[Terence Burns, Baron Burns|Lord Terry Burns]].
Abraham became immediately involved in programming issues such as whether [[Jonathan Ross]] should return,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/mar/19/jonathan-ross-channel-4|title=Jonathan Ross chatshow deal shelved by Channel 4|last=Plunkett|first=John|date=2010-03-19|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-04-15}}</ref> and in defending a controversial [[Frankie Boyle]] sketch about [[Katie Price]]'s family.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/nov/02/frankie-boyle-sketches-broadcast-racist|title=Frankie Boyle sketches 'wouldn't have been broadcast if they were racist'|last=Plunkett|first=John|date=2 November 2012|work=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref>
Abraham assembled a new leadership team including appointing [[Jay Hunt (television executive)|Jay Hunt]] from [[BBC One]] as chief creative officer to revive programming.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/sep/14/jay-hunt-channel-4|title=Channel 4 appoints Jay Hunt as chief creative officer|last=Brown|first=Maggie|date=14 September 2010|work=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref> Over the next few years, Channel 4's programmes included ''24 Hours in A&E'', ''The 2012 Paralympic Games'', ''The Grand National'', ''Black Mirror'', ''Gogglebox'', ''The Last Leg'', ''Humans'', ''The Undateables'', ''Educating Yorkshire'', ''The Island'', ''Indian Summers'', ''Southcliffe'', ''UKIP; The First 100 Days'', ''Sri Lanka's Killing Fields'', ''Benefits Street'', ''Big Fat Gypsy Weddings'' and ''MPs For Hire''.
In 2010 and 2014, Channel 4 was named Channel of the Year at the [[Edinburgh International Television Festival]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/aug/23/channel-4-channel-year-edinburgh-tv-festival|title=Channel 4 wins channel of the year at Edinburgh TV festival|last=Plunkett|first=John|date=23 August 2014|work=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref> and by ''[[Broadcast (magazine)|Broadcast]]'' magazine in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-35548079|title=Channel 4 wins Channel of the Year at Broadcast Awards|publisher=BBC News|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref>
In late 2015, Abraham and Hunt struck a three-year deal with [[Bernie Ecclestone]] to broadcast [[Formula One]] on Channel 4.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/2b7fe040-a7dc-11e5-955c-1e1d6de94879.html#axzz41MyHnTUa|title=Channel 4 snaps up live F1 after BBC ditches TV coverage|last=Mance|first=Henry|date=21 December 2015|work=Financial Times|issn=0307-1766|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref> In early 2015, Channel 4 launched new online hub All 4, offering live streaming, shortform and 'box-set' content, and replacing 4oD.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/sep/11/channel-4-replace-4od-new-online-hub-streaming-tablets-smartphones|title=Channel 4 to replace 4oD with new online hub All 4|last=Sweney|first=Mark|date=11 September 2014|work=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref> In early 2016, a new foreign language drama service called Walter Presents was launched on All 4.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaltveurope.net/380871/channel-4-to-roll-out-new-vod-service-4world-drama/|title=Channel 4 to roll out new VoD service 4World Drama » Digital TV Europe|website=www.digitaltveurope.net|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref>
Abraham increased funding for [[Film4]] in 2010<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/film-4-renaissance-set-to-continue-1964118.html|title=Film 4 renaissance set to continue|website=The Independent|language=en-GB|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref> and again in 2016<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/film4-funding-increased-to-record-36m-signs-fox-searchlight-deal/5100007.article?referrer=RSS|title=Film4 funding increased to record $36m; signs Fox Searchlight deal|website=www.screendaily.com|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref> and the film division led by [[Tessa Ross]] and subsequently David Kosse.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/aug/04/film4-appoints-david-kosse-as-director-to-succeed-tessa-ross|title=Film4 appoints David Kosse as director to succeed Tessa Ross|last=Pulver|first=Andrew|date=4 August 2014|work=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref> In 2016 Abraham appointed [[Daniel Battsek]] to lead Film 4 following the leaving of David Kosse to join [[STX Entertainment|STX]].
In 2010, Abraham and Burns pursued a bid to acquire Channel 5. This was ultimately secured by [[Richard Desmond]]'s Northern and Shell.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/jun/04/channel-4-channel-five|title=Channel 4 barred by law from buying Five|last=Robinson|first=James|date=4 June 2010|work=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref>
Abraham's other business initiatives at Channel 4 have included: a new advertising sales partnership with UKTV<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/info/press/news/uktv-and-channel-4-agree-10-year-ad-sales-deal|title=UKTV and Channel 4 agree 10-year ad sales deal - Channel 4 - Info - Press|publisher=Channel 4|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref> (and later, BT Sport). A new on-line data strategy which has over 13 million registered users across the UK<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.computerweekly.com/feature/CW500-Channel-4-crunches-data-for-a-competitive-edge|title=CW500: Why Channel 4 is crunching big data|website=ComputerWeekly|language=en-GB|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref> and the launch of 4seven.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-17311528|title=Channel 4 announces 4seven catch-up channel|website=BBC News|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref> In 2011 Abraham hired Jonathan Allen as Sales Director<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/article/1078299/reaction-channel-4s-surprise-appointment-jonathan-allan|title=Reaction to Channel 4's surprise appointment of Jonathan Allan|work=Media Week|date=4 July 2011|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref> who built a team than won Sales Team of the Year in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/info/press/news/4-sales-named-media-week-s-sales-team-of-the-year-2015|title=4 Sales named Media Week's Sales Team of the Year 2015|publisher=Channel 4|accessdate=15 April 2016}}</ref>
Dan Brooke also joined the Channel 4 as director of marketing and communications<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/dan-brooke-confirmed-marketing-leader-channel-4/1037253|title=Dan Brooke confirmed as marketing leader of Channel 4|website=www.campaignlive.co.uk|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref> and then Chief Marketing and Communications Officer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/info/corporate/about/channel-4-board|title=Channel 4 Board - Channel 4 - Info - Corporate|website=www.channel4.com|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref> Channel 4’s in-house agency 4Creative have created campaigns such as ''Meet The Superhumans''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dandad.org/en/d-ad-meet-the-superhumans-case-study-tv-ad/|title=Case Study: Meet The Superhumans|publisher=D&AD|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref> in 2012 and the rebranding of Channel 4 in 2015 created by the film-maker [[Jonathan Glazer]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.creativereview.co.uk/cr-blog/2015/september/channel-4-rebrands-with-help-from-jonathan-glazer-and-neville-brody/|title=Channel 4 rebrands, with help from Jonathan Glazer and Neville Brody – Creative Review|website=www.creativereview.co.uk|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref>
In June 2017, it was announced that Abraham would leave later that year and would be succeeded by [[Alex Mahon]] as the CEO of Channel 4.<ref>{{cite web|author=Mark Sweney |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2017/jun/05/channel-4-alex-mahon-chief-executive-shine-foundry |title=Channel 4 confirms Alex Mahon as chief executive | Media |publisher=The Guardian |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2017-06-05}}</ref> Mahon formally took over the role in October 2017.<ref name="channel4">{{cite web|url=https://www.channel4.com/corporate/about-4/who-we-are/board |title=Discover our Board|publisher=Channel 4 |accessdate=13 November 2017}}</ref>
== Wonderhood Studios == In April 2018, Abraham announced<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2018/tv/news/david-abraham-wonderhood-studios-channel-4-1202756824/|title=Former Channel 4 Chief David Abraham Launches Wonderhood Studios|last=Clarke|first=Stewart|date=2018-04-18|work=Variety|access-date=2018-04-18|language=en-US}}</ref> the launch of a new company, Wonderhood Studios. The stated aims of the business are to forge a new model in the creative industries by bringing together skills and capabilities that until now have operated separately. The new company will be structured in the form of adjacent studios: one will produce ambitious programming across multiple genres for broadcasters and platforms while another will serve as a full-strength creative agency for major brands. Both studios will be supported by a third specialism in media data insight and the development of future digital networks.
== Media industry contributions == In May 2011, Abraham set out his planned vision for Channel 4 at a [[Royal Television Society]] event in which he stressed the importance of its organisational independence and how it would keep innovating both editorially and technologically.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/may/24/david-abraham-rts-speech-full|title=David Abraham's Royal Television Society speech: full text|date=2011-05-24|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-04-15}}</ref> On the occasion of the 30th Anniversary of Channel 4 in 2012, he delivered a speech at the Freeword Centre London entitled: Freedom of Expression and Free Television.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.englishpen.org/campaigns/freedom-of-expression-and-free-television-david-abraham-speech/|title=Freedom of Expression and Free Television - David Abraham Speech - English PEN|website=English PEN|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-15}}</ref>
In 2013 Abraham chaired the Royal Television Society Cambridge Convention during which he announced a new £20m Growth Fund for UK independent production companies.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/9d111ccc-2887-11e4-9ea9-00144feabdc0.html#axzz45VS4aCn8|title=Channel 4 takes stakes in TV programme makers|last=Mance|first=Henry|date=2014-08-21|newspaper=Financial Times|issn=0307-1766|access-date=2016-04-15}}</ref> This fund has invested in companies such as Lightbox, True North, Arrow, Eleven Films and production entities involving [[Sacha Baron Cohen]] and [[David Coulthard]].
In 2014, Abraham delivered the MacTaggart Lecture at the Edinburgh International Television Festival.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/aug/21/david-abraham-mactaggart-lecture-full-text|title=David Abraham’s MacTaggart lecture - full text|last=Abraham|first=David|date=21 August 2014|work=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref> The theme of the lecture addressed the continuing importance of public service broadcasting in the UK in an age of global and technological consolidation. The lecture caused debate within the media industry and was characterised by some as a critique of American ownership of UK media assets.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/david-abraham-big-ideas-for-the-small-screen-9686810.html|title=David Abraham: Big ideas for the small screen|work=The Independent|language=en-GB|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref>
Following the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|May 2015 general election]], Abraham, together with Channel 4 chairman Terry Burns,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/nov/08/channel-4-sell-off-little-financial-benefit-chairman-lord-burns|title=Channel 4 sell-off would have little financial benefit, says chairman|last=Martinson|first=Jane|date=8 November 2015|work=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref> has spoken out<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Jackson|first1=Jasper|last2=Sweney|first2=Mark|last3=Plunkett|first3=John|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/oct/13/privatised-channel-4-need-profits-200m-year-ceo|title=Privatised Channel 4 would need profits of £200m a year, says chief executive|work=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|date=13 October 2015|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref> about the potential threats to public service broadcasting and to the UK creative economy in the event of the privatisation of Channel 4.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/mediatechnologyandtelecoms/media/11671049/SUNDAY-INTERVIEW-Channel-4-chief-David-Abraham-prepares-for-privatisation-battlechannel-4-humans-david-abraham.html|title=Channel 4 chief prepares for privatisation battle|work=The Telegraph|date=13 June 2015|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/mediatechnologyandtelecoms/12069831/It-will-be-a-grand-prize-for-its-buyer-but-where-is-the-formula-to-put-a-value-on-Channel-4.html|title=It will be a grand prize for its buyer - but where is the formula to put a value on Channel 4?|work=The Telegraph|date=26 December 2015|access-date=15 April 2016}}</ref>
Abraham is a Vice President of the Royal Television Society,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://rts.org.uk/article/royal-television-society-announces-new-appointments|title=Royal Television Society announces new appointments {{!}} Royal Television Society|website=rts.org.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-04-06}}</ref> a member of [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts|BAFTA]] and has sat on the board of Creative Skillset since 2008.
==Personal life== Abraham lives in London, is a father to two adult children and partner to Tiina Lee, Head of Global Markets and Deputy Chief Executive for Deutsche Bank UK.

{{short description|Satirical observation by Dilbert cartoonist Scott Adams}} The '''Dilbert principle''' is a concept in [[management]] developed by [[Scott Adams]], creator of the comic strip ''[[Dilbert]]'', which states that companies tend to systematically promote [[Competence (human resources)|incompetent]] employees to management to get them out of the workflow. The Dilbert principle is inspired by the [[Peter principle]], which holds that employees are promoted based on success in their current position until they reach their "level of incompetence" and are no longer promoted. Under the Dilbert principle, employees who were never competent are promoted to management to limit the damage they can do. Adams first explained the principle in a 1995 ''[[The Wall Street Journal|Wall Street Journal]]'' article, and expanded upon it in his 1996 business book ''The Dilbert Principle''. ==Definition== In the ''Dilbert'' strip of February 5, 1995, [[Dogbert]] says that "leadership is nature's way of removing morons from the productive flow". Adams himself explained,{{cite news|title=Funny Business |author= |url=http://www.aacsb.edu/publications/bized/p16-21.pdf |newspaper=BizEd |date=November–December 2002 |accessdate=April 23, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206065944/http://aacsb.edu/publications/bized/p16-21.pdf |archivedate=February 6, 2009 }}
I wrote ''The Dilbert Principle'' around the concept that in many cases the least competent, least smart people are promoted, simply because they’re the ones you don't want doing actual work. You want them ordering the doughnuts and yelling at people for not doing their assignments—you know, the easy work. Your heart surgeons and your computer programmers—your smart people—aren't in management. That principle was literally happening everywhere.
Adams explained the principle in a 1995 ''[[The Wall Street Journal|Wall Street Journal]]'' article.Adams, Scott. "Manager's journal: The Dilbert principle." ''Wall Street Journal'' [New York, N.Y.] 22 May 1995, Eastern edition: A12. ''Wall Street Journal''. Adams then expanded his study of the Dilbert principle in his 1996 book ''The Dilbert Principle'', which is required or recommended reading at some management and [[Master of Business Administration|business programs]].{{cite web |url=http://mot.berkeley.edu/Berkeley_Students/Students/Courses/Course_Descriptions/proj_mgmt_syll.pdf |title=Project Management Case Studies |work=Haas School of Business |publisher=University of California, Berkeley |date=2003 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313051719/http://mot.berkeley.edu/Berkeley_Students/Students/Courses/Course_Descriptions/proj_mgmt_syll.pdf |archivedate=March 13, 2012 |accessdate=October 17, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cs.colorado.edu/~hendrixs/classes/readings.html |title=Readings for CSCI 3308 - Software Engineering Methods and Tools |publisher=University of Colorado Boulder |date=March 16, 2001 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060922194230/http://www.cs.colorado.edu/~hendrixs/classes/readings.html |archivedate=September 22, 2006 |accessdate=October 17, 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www.vancouver.wsu.edu/fac/holt/em501/em501.htm |title=Syllabus - SW Project Mgt - CSE5315 - 1998 |accessdate=2010-02-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030220024018/http://www.vancouver.wsu.edu/fac/holt/em501/em501.htm |archivedate=February 20, 2003 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.vancouver.wsu.edu/fac/holt/em501/em501.htm |title=EM 501 Management of Organizations |publisher=Washington State University |date=2000 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100209050420/http://www.vancouver.wsu.edu/fac/holt/em501/em501.htm |archivedate=February 9, 2010 |accessdate=October 17, 2015}} In the book, Adams writes that, in terms of effectiveness, use of the Dilbert principle is akin to a band of gorillas choosing an alpha-squirrel to lead them. The book has sold more than a million copies and was on the ''New York Times'' bestseller list for 43 weeks. Adams' presentation of the principle is [[satire|satirical]]—facetious but also addressing a real-world concern. ==Comparative principles== The Dilbert principle is comparable to the [[Peter principle]]. As opposed to the Dilbert principle, the Peter principle assumes that people are promoted because they are competent, and that the tasks higher up in the hierarchy require skills or talents they do not possess. It concludes that due to this, a competent employee will eventually be promoted to, and then remain at, a position at which he or she is incompetent. In his book, ''The Peter Principle'', [[Laurence J. Peter]] explains "percussive sublimation", the act of kicking a person upstairs (i.e., promoting him to management) to get him out of the way of productive employees. The Dilbert principle, by contrast, assumes that hierarchy just serves as a means for removing the incompetent to "higher" positions where they will be unable to cause damage to the workflow, assuming that the upper echelons of an organization have little relevance to its actual production, and that the majority of real, productive work in a company is done by people lower in the power ladder. Unlike the Peter principle, the promoted individuals were not particularly good at any job they previously held, so placing them in a supervisory position is a way to quietly remove them from the workforce without actually firing them, rather than a reward for meritorious service. An earlier formulation of this effect was known as [[Putt's Law]]. ==See also== *{{annotated link|Negative selection (politics)}} ==References== {{Spoken Wikipedia|The_Dilbert_Principle.ogg|2005-06-26}} {{reflist}} ==Further reading== {{refbegin}} * ''The Dilbert Principle'' by Scott Adams, HarperBusiness (1996) {{ISBN|0-88730-858-9}}. {{refend}} {{Dilbert}} [[Category:1996 books]] [[Category:Organizational theory]] [[Category:Incompetence]] [[Category:Business books]] [[Category:Dilbert books]]

|1888|1938|end=died}} | parents = Kepple Elias Disney
Mary Richardson | children = [[Disney family|Herbert Arthur Disney]]
[[Disney family|Raymond Arnold Disney]]
[[Roy O. Disney|Roy Oliver Disney]]
[[Walt Disney|Walter Elias Disney]]
[[Disney family|Ruth Flora Disney]] }} '''Elias Charles Disney''' (February 6, 1859{{spaced ndash}}September 13, 1941){{Cite web|url=https://billiongraves.com/grave/Elias-Disney/19970346|title=Elias Disney (1859-1941) Grave Site {{!}} BillionGraves|website=BillionGraves|language=en|access-date=2017-08-13}} was the father of [[Roy O. Disney|Roy]] and [[Walt Disney]]. ==Early life== Disney was born at the rural village of [[Morris-Turnberry, Ontario|Bluevale]], in what is now [[Ontario]], Canada, to [[Irish people|Irish]] [[Irish Protestants|Protestant]] immigrants Kepple Elias Disney (1832–1891) and Mary Richardson (1838–1909). Both parents had emigrated from [[Ireland]] to Canada as children, accompanying their parents.Barrier (2007), p. 12 He became a farmer and a businessman with little success. He moved to [[California]] with his father in 1878 in hopes of finding [[gold]]. Instead, Kepple was convinced by an agent of the [[Union Pacific Railroad]] to buy {{convert|200|acre|ha}} of land near [[Ellis, Kansas|Ellis]], [[Kansas]]. Disney was an ardent [[socialist]] and a supporter of [[Eugene Debs]].Schlosser. Fast Food Nation. p. 36Barrier (2007), p. 13 In Ellis, Elias attempted to live as an orange grower and failed.Barrier (2007), p. 12 ==Career== [[Image:Elias-Disney.jpg|thumb|right|Elias' son, Walt, paid tribute to his father with a small sign on his Main Street USA attraction at Disneyland which is still in place today. It reads, "ELIAS DISNEY, CONTRACTOR, EST. 1895."]] Disney worked on his father's new farm until 1884, when he left to find another job. He was hired in a railroad machine shop (one of his co-workers was [[Walter Chrysler]]), then he joined the railroad crew building the Union Pacific line through [[Colorado]]. After the railroad contract was over, he became a professional [[fiddle]] player in [[Denver, Colorado|Denver]]. Again he was unsuccessful, and he returned to his father's farm. He also worked for a short time as a mailman in [[Kissimmee]], Florida, close to the eventual site of [[Walt Disney World]]. Disney did also attempt to make a career as an orange grower in Florida, but he was unsuccessful {{cite book|last1=Barrier|first1=Michael|title=The Animated Man|date=2007|publisher=University of California Press|location=Los Angeles, California|isbn=978-0-520-24117-6|page=12 of 393}} As one can see{{weasel inline|date=November 2016}} from his attempts at being self-employed, Elias had entrepreneurial tendencies—tendencies that his son, Walt, later would inherit and develop. He was a construction worker for the 1893 [[World's Columbian Exposition]] in Chicago, an event which author [[Erik Larson (author)|Erik Larson]] cites as a source of inspiration for his son Walt and the Disney kingdom he would eventually create.{{cite web | url=http://www.randomhouse.com/crown/devilinthewhitecity/fair.html | title=The Devil In The White City | first=Erik | last=Larson | publisher=[[Random House]] | accessdate=2009-12-19}} He bought shares of O-Zell Company, a jelly-canning factory that also produced apple juice in Chicago, where his son Walt Disney worked before he joined the Red Cross Ambulance Corps in World War I.{{cite book|last=Barrier|first=Michael|title=The Animated Man - A life of Walt Disney|year=2007|publisher=University of Los Angeles Press|location=Los Angeles|isbn=978-0-520-24117-6|pages=19–22}} ==Family== Disney married [[Flora Call Disney|Flora Call]] on January 1, 1888, in Kismet, Lake County, FL {{convert|50|mi|km}} north of the land on which [[Walt Disney World]] would eventually be built and lived for a short time in adjoining [[Acron, Florida|Acron]], [[Florida]].[http://www.randomhouse.com/catalog/display.pperl?isbn=9780307265968&view=excerpt ''Walt Disney'' by Neal Gabler - eBook - Random House] at www.randomhouse.com She was the daughter of his father's neighbors. Soon after marriage, the Disneys moved to [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]], [[Illinois]], where Elias met and befriended [[Walter Parr]], St. Paul Congregational Church's preacher for whom the Disneys' fourth son, Walt, was named. Elias' son Raymond Arnold Disney named his son Charles Elias Disney after his father Elias Charles Disney.Barrier (2007), p. 13 The couple had five children: *Herbert Arthur Disney (December 8, 1888 – January 29, 1961, aged 72) *Raymond Arnold Disney (December 30, 1890 – May 24, 1989, aged 98) *[[Roy O. Disney|Roy Oliver Disney]] (June 24, 1893 – December 20, 1971, aged 78) *[[Walt Disney|Walter "Walt" Elias Disney]] (December 5, 1901 – December 15, 1966, aged 65) *Ruth Flora Disney (December 6, 1903 – April 7, 1995, aged 91) ==Wanderings== By 1890, the Disneys lived at 3515 South Vernon Avenue in the Fourth Ward. Elias worked as a carpenter.Barrier (2007), p. 9-10 On October 31, 1891, Elias bought a lot at '''1249 Tripp'''.{{cite web|url=http://www.thewaltdisneybirthplace.org/|title=Home - The Walt Disney Birthplace|work=The Walt Disney Birthplace|accessdate= May 31, 2015}} By 1892 he built a house on it. The neighborhood was called Hermosa and had been settled by Scottish, German, and Scandinavian immigrants. Their younger three children were born there. [http://www.thewaltdisneybirthplace.org/]Barrier (2007), p. 9-10 By the turn of the century, Elias had become an active building contractor. He built houses which he owned and then resold. He also built the Saint Paul Congregational Church, a building dedicated on October 14, 1900. Elias was one of the church's trustees, while his wife was its treasurer.Barrier (2007), p. 13 According to some sources,{{who|date=November 2016}} Disney worried about the rising criminality of the city. A neighboring family had two adolescent children involved in a car barn robbery, and Elias feared that crime would taint his own children.Barrier (2007), p. 9-10 In 1906 he moved with his family to a farm near [[Marceline, Missouri|Marceline]], [[Missouri]]. Elias and his family settled there in April, 1906. On March 5, he bought a {{convert|40|acre|ha|adj=on}} farm. Its previous owner William E. Crane had died in November, 1905. Crane was a veteran of the [[American Civil War]] and his house predated the foundation of Marceline.Barrier (2007), p. 9-10 He bought the farm for $3,000 or $75 per acre. On April 3, Elias bought an adjoining tract of about {{convert|5|acre|ha|0}} from Crane's widow. He paid an additional $450.Barrier (2007), p. 9-10 Marceline was probably{{weasel inline|date=November 2016}} chosen for being accessible from Chicago, for its rural setting, and because his younger brother Robert owned a {{convert|440|acre|ha|adj=on}} farm west of the city.Barrier (2007), p. 9-10 The Crane Farm had orchards of apples, peaches, and plums, and fields of grain. The farm animals included pigs, chickens, horses, and cows.Barrier (2007), p. 11 The Disneys had a telephone connection by 1907.Barrier (2007), p. 11 Herbert and Raymond Disney never liked life on the farm. They moved out around the fall of 1908, heading back to Chicago. They found work as clerks.Barrier (2007), p. 14 In 1907, Elias convinced some of his fellow farmers to join the American Society of Equity, a farmer's union aiming to consolidate the members' buying power.Barrier (2007), p. 16-17 The family sold the farm on November 28, 1910, as Elias fell ill. He was suffering from [[typhoid fever]], followed by [[pneumonia]].Barrier (2007), p. 16-17 The Disneys lived in a rented house in Marceline, probably at 508 North Kansas Avenue. Until 1911, when they moved to [[Kansas City, Missouri]]. They lived in a rented house at 2706 East Thirty-first Street. They stayed there until they bought their own modest home in September, 1914. It was situated at 3028 Bellefontaine Street.Barrier (2007), p. 16-17{{cite web|title=Disney, Walt, House and Garage|url=http://www.dnr.mo.gov/shpo/nps-nr/78001654.pdf||work=dnr.mo.gov}} On July 1, 1911, Elias purchased a newspaper delivery route for ''[[The Kansas City Star]]''. It extended from the Twenty-seventh Street to the Thirty-first Street, and from Prospect Avenue to Indiana Avenue. Roy and Walt were put to work delivering the newspapers. The Disneys delivered the morning newspaper ''[[Kansas City Times]]'' to about 700 customers and the evening and Sunday ''Star'' to more than 600. Their customers increased with time.Barrier (2007), p. 18 Elias also delivered butter and eggs to his newspaper customers. They were imported from a dairy farm in Marceline.Barrier (2007), pp. 19-20 Elias sold the paper route on March 17, 1917. He had been investing in the O-Zell Company of Chicago since 1912 and moved back to the city in 1917 to take an active role in its management. The Disneys rented a flat at 1523 Ogden Avenue.Barrier (2007), p. 21 He retired from management work in 1920 and moved back to Kansas City. He was again listed as a carpenter.Barrier (2007), p. 27-28 He moved to [[Portland, Oregon]] by the fall (autumn September–October) of 1921. His son Herbert had earlier moved to this city.Barrier (2007), pp. 29-30 ==Character== Disney was a member of the Congregational Church and often preached stern sermons on Sundays in this church. His son, Walter Elias Disney, was named after a Congregationalist minister named Walter Parr. Walt's middle name was after his father, Elias Charles Disney. Elias and Walt had a tense relationship as Elias never saw Walt's profession as an artist as a real job.{{cite book |last1=Thomas|first1=Bob |title=Building a Company|date=1998|publisher=Hyperion|location=New York|isbn=0-7868-6200-9|page=15 of 359|edition=First}} Elias' son Raymond Arnold Disney named his son Charles Elias Disney after his father Elias Charles Disney. Elias [[Teetotalism|never drank alcohol]] and rarely smoked.Barrier (2007), p. 13 According to biographical accounts, Disney was a stern man who could have a strong temper at times,Barrier (2007), p. 14 and would take the money his sons earned for "safekeeping", considering them too young to know the value of money. If his children misbehaved, Elias would not hesitate to punish them with a switch. Elias would talk socialism with strange characters and bring them home. He was a fiddler and would bring home anyone else who could play an instrument.Barrier (2007), p. 15 ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Sources== * {{citation | last1=Barrier | first1= J. Michael. | title=The Animated Man: A Life of Walt Disney | chapter= The Pet in the Family: On the Farm and in the City, 1901-1923| year=2007 | publisher=[[University of California Press]]| isbn=978-0520241176| url =https://books.google.com/books?id=h2JaDDqOiJkC&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22Buckaroo+Bugs%27%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=CoJwU7qlB-yZ0QWnu4CgBw&ved=0CFUQ6AEwCTgK#v=onepage&q&f=false}} ==External links== {{Portal|Biography}} * {{Find a Grave|8808}} * [http://www.michaelbarrier.com/Essays/Elias%20Disney/DisneyFamilyInCanada.html Biography of the Disney Family in Canada] * {{IMDb name|1091985|Elias Charles Disney}} (documentary footage) * [http://disneyparks.disney.go.com/blog/2013/06/windows-on-main-street-u-s-a-at-disneyland-park-elias-disney/ Windows on Main Street, U.S.A., at Disneyland Park: Elias Disney] * [http://disney2disney.com] {{DEFAULTSORT:Disney, Elias}} [[Category:1859 births]] [[Category:1941 deaths]] [[Category:Canadian people of Irish descent]] [[Category:Canadian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:People from Huron County, Ontario]] [[Category:Burials at Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Glendale)]] [[Category:Union Pacific Railroad people]] [[Category:Canadian farmers]] [[Category:Canadian Congregationalists]] [[Category:Canadian Christian socialists]] [[Category:American Congregationalists]] [[Category:American Christian socialists]] [[Category:Disney family|Elias]] [[Category:Congregationalist socialists]] [[Category:People from Marceline, Missouri]] [[pl:Walt Disney#Rodzina]]

'''Entrepreneurial feminism''', developed from [[social feminism]], is a theory that explains how feminist values are enacted through the venture creation process to improve the position of women in society.<ref>Orser, B., Elliott, C., & Leck, J., 2011. Feminist attributes and entrepreneurial identity, Gender in Management: An International Journal, 26(8): 561-589.</ref><ref>Ahl, H., and Tillmar, M. (2015). Swedish welfare state retrenchment and the call for women’s entrepreneurship to fill the void. Paper presented at The 4th European Conference on Politics and Gender 2015 June 11-13 Uppsala, Sweden.</ref> Coined by [[Barbara Jayne Orser|Barbara Orser]] and Catherine Elliott, entrepreneurship is viewed as a mechanism to create economic self-sufficiency and equity-based outcomes for girls and women.<ref>Yasmine, R. (2016). Entrepreneurial Feminism: Where Entrepreneurship Intersects Feminist Thinking. Whatsyourtech.ca. Accessed on August 19, 2016 at http://whatsyourtech.ca/2016/08/05/entrepreneurial-feminism-where-entrepreneurship-intersects-feminist-thinking/</ref><ref>Orser, B. & Elliott, C. (2015). [http://www.sup.org/books/title/?id=22349 Feminine Capital. Unlocking the Power of Women Entrepreneurs], Stanford University Press.</ref> Entrepreneurial feminists enter commercial markets to create wealth and social change, based on the ethics of cooperation, equality, and mutual respect.<ref>Orser, B., Elliott, C., & Leck, J., 2011. Feminist attributes and entrepreneurial identity, Gender in Management: An International Journal, 26(8): 561-589.</ref>

[[Image:Eva Swartz in Dec 2013.jpg|thumb|220px|right|Eva Swartz in 2013.]] '''Eva Birgitta Swartz Grimaldi''', (born 15 April 1956) is a [[Swedes|Swedish]] [[CEO]] within the field of culture and media. On 28 June 2007, she was appointed as chairman for investigation into the future of the Swedish culture politics by the Swedish culture minister [[Lena Adelsohn Liljeroth]].<ref name="regeringen.se">[http://www.regeringen.se/sb/d/9075/a/84986 Regeringen] Retrieved 14 October 2015 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203050239/http://www.regeringen.se/sb/d/9075/a/84986 |date=December 3, 2013 }}</ref> Swartz became the CEO of the book publishers [[Natur & Kultur]] on 15 April 2005. Before that she was programme director at [[TV4 (Sweden)|TV4]] and had a number of CEO roles within the television industry. She was amongst other things the CEO of the production company Meter Film & Television.<ref name="stadsbrudskaren.se">{{cite web|url=http://stadsbrudskaren.se/eva-swartz-grimaldi-ny-ordforande/|title=Eva Swartz Grimaldi ny ordförande - Stadsbrudskåren|publisher=|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref>
Swartz is the vice [[CEO]] of the board of Svenska Filminstitutet (Swedish Film Institute), a position she held until 31 December 2010.<ref>[http://www.regeringen.se/sb/d/9760/a/94950 Eva Swartz - Regeringen ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203032735/http://www.regeringen.se/sb/d/9760/a/94950 |date=2013-12-03 }} Retrieved 14 October 2015</ref> She was also a member of the Nobelstiftelsens media company Nobel Media.<ref name="stadsbrudskaren.se"/> She has been the responsible for the information for Italienska kulturinstituet for [[Italy]] and work as an interpreter and translator.<ref name="sydsvenskan.se">{{cite web|url=http://www.sydsvenskan.se/familj/fodelsedag/chef-med-kansla-for-kultur/|title=Chef med känsla för kultur|work=Sydsvenskan|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref> Since 1 January 2013, she has been the chairman for Norstedt Förlagsgrupp.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mynewsdesk.com/se/norstedts/pressreleases/eva-swartz-grimaldi-blir-styrelseordfoerande-foer-norstedts-foerlagsgrupp-823640|title=Eva Swartz Grimaldi blir styrelseordförande för Norstedts Förlagsgrupp|work=Mynewsdesk|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref> In 2014, she became the new chairman of the Stadsbrudskåren, a non profit organisation that was founded in 1965.<ref name="stadsbrudskaren.se"/> She always pushes for culture and media within her work as CEO and chairman.<ref name="sydsvenskan.se"/>
She is married to the Italian industrialist [[Salvatore Grimaldi]], and the couple live in [[Villa Geber]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/avsnitt/71997?programid=3164|title=Ulf Elfving möter Eva Swartz Grimaldi och Salvatore Grimaldi|author=Sveriges Radio|publisher=|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref>

{{Multiple issues| {{Peacock|date=November 2018}} {{BLP sources|date=November 2018}}}} {{infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Hans Mortensen | honorific_suffix = | image = Hans Mortensen 2012.png | alt = | caption = Mortensen in 2012 | birthname = Hans Mortensen | birth_date = {{Birth date|1943|8|2|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Tórshavn, Faroe Islands]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = {{flagicon|Faroe Islands}} [[Faroese Islands|Faroese]] | occupation = CEO, entrepreneur, merchant, handball player | years_active = 1963-2007 | awards = Faroese Mother Language Award 2015 | parents = [[Niels Gustav Mortensen]] and [[Ebba Mortensen]] | spouse = [[Birgith Aslaugh Mortensen]] (m. 1964)
[[Marjun á Plógv]] (m. 2007) | children = Two }} '''Hans Mortensen''' (born 2 September [[1943]] at [[Tórshavn]], [[Faroe Islands]]), is a retired [[Faroe Islands|Faroese]] [[Businessperson|businessman]] and [[Entrepreneurship|entrepreneur]]. He is famous for founding and managing the biggest department store in [[Tórshavn]], [[SMS]], and is also recognised for his contribution in introducing trade and business terminology into the [[Faroese language]]. Between 1963 and 1976 he was a driving force in developing elite handball in the Faroe Islands. == Personal life == Mortensen was born and raised in Tórshavn in the Faroe Islands. He is the son of business owners Niels Gustav Mortensen (1913 – 1987) and Ebba Mortensen (1920 – 2000), who each ran trading businesses in one of the older trading quarters of Tórshavn between 1952 and 1990.{{cite web|url=http://pfformula.ipapercms.dk/SMS/SMSbl/SMSbl2012/SMSbloktober2012/|title=SMS : Hans Mortensen|date=November 2012|website=Pfformula.ipapercms.dk|accessdate=7 November 2018}} In 1964, he married Birgit Mortensen (née Sivertsen), and together they had a daughter, Elisabeth Mortensen and a son, Niels Mortensen. Niels Mortensen took over as CEO of SMS after his father stepped down from the position in 1996, and as a member of its board after Mortensen retired in 2007. After being a widower since 2001, Mortensen remarried in 2007 with Marjun á Plógv. == Education == After completing primary and secondary school, Mortensen received his Upper Secondary diploma from [[Føroya Millum- og Realskúli]] and took on an apprenticeship at Føroya Banki (now [[BankNordik]]). In 1967, Mortensen graduated from the [[Niels Brock]] business school in [[Copenhagen]] and shortly after started working at the [[Magasin du Nord]] department store on [[Kongens Nytorv]] in Copenhagen. After two years at the department store, Mortensen returned to the Faroe Islands to found his own business and improve the lagging business conditions in the country. == Sport == Mortensen’s life-long commitment to Faroese elite [[handball]] began in the 1960s and 1970s. In 1963, at the age of 18, Mortensen became the president of the Tórshavn handball club [[Neistin]] and immediately initiated the construction of a club venue, completed in the following year. The venue was crucial to the club’s subsequent popularity and success.{{cite web|url=http://www.hvannrok.fo/2016/03/30/neistaeldsalin-hans-mortensen-var-framsiggin-hondboltsleidari/|title=Neistaeldsálin Hans Mortensen var framsíggin hondbóltsleiðari - Hvannrók|website=Hvannrok.fo|accessdate=7 November 2018}} In 1964, Mortensen played on the first Faroese men’s national handball team. In 1976, Mortensen was head coach for the men’s national handball team when they achieved good results during the Men’s Handball World Championship 1976 Group C in [[Portugal]].{{cite web|url=http://www.todor66.com/handball/World/Men_C_1976.html|title=Men Handball World Championship 1976 Group C Portugal - 26.11-01.12 Winner Portugal|first=Todor|last=Krastev|website=Todor66.com|accessdate=7 November 2018}} == Career == After completing his education in [[Denmark]], Mortensen ran his own retail business in his parents’ premises in central Tórshavn. But in 1970, Mortensen organised the first of many trade fairs in the Faroe Islands. A few attempts had been made earlier at arranging similar events in 1968 in Klaksvík. Cf. Tingakrossur no. 29 – 26 July 1968, p. 4 The popularity of the trade fairs showed that demand for the Faroese market was bigger than the market was capable of supplying at the time. Most businesses were located in central Torshavn, and increasing traffic and construction was causing congestion. Tórshavn's city council was therefore planning to establish a shopping street as an extension of a new pharmacy at the outskirts of the city centre to divert some of the traffic.Dagblaðið no. 43 – 28 juli 1976, p. 4Hoydal, Gunnar: Sosialurin no. 78 – 7 July 1984, p. 11 Upon learning of the city plans and the reasons behind them, Mortensen suggested privatising the project in order to further promote business. After initial internal disputes, Mortensen was granted permission to build his department store, which would enable customers to run various errands in a single location. Mortensen hired Danish architect Flemming Hansen to design a progressive department store, whose architecture would still be rooted in traditional Faroese building style. Construction began in 1976, and the department store SMS opened to the public on November 2nd, 1977. Mortensen was CEO of SMS from 1976 to 1996 and majority shareholder until 2007, when he sold all his shares to his son Niels Mortensen. Niels Mortensen has since then developed the business further. Today the SMS Group includes three shopping centers, three chain stores, a number of partnerships and a microbiological laboratory. == Business and visions == Mortensen’s visions have been characterised by both progressiveness and traditionalism. The department store SMS was designed to resemble traditional Faroese boathouses, and Faroese shop names and business terminology was developed by taking into account common citizen and customer opinions, often through public naming competitions. Over time, the previous predominately Danish business terminology was replaced by newly created Faroese terminology, which continues to evolve with the introduction of new terms and technology. In an effort to combine innovation with historic preservation, Mortensen collaborated with architects Gunnar Hoydal, Mette Skjold, and Ósbjørn Jacobsen in 2012 to create a public proposal on how to continue developing the Tórshavn city centre while maintaining its historic features.Hoydal, Gunnar et al, Havnin innan fyri Stóragarð: hugsjónir og dreymar, Tórshavn 2012 == Awards == On International Mother Language Day in 2015, Mortensen received the Faroese Mother Language Award for his longstanding contribution to society and language, particularly his innovative approaches to Faroese trade and business.{{cite web|url=http://snar.fo/tema/skaldskapur-og-midlar/modurmalid/modurmalsvirdisloen/|title=Móðurmálsvirðisløn|website=Snar.fo|accessdate=7 November 2018}} == Literature == * Justinussen, Jens Christian Svabo: Fanget i fisken? En analyse af den politiske økonomi på Færøerne i efterkrigstiden, Speciale, Roskilde Universitetscenter. Institut for Miljø, Teknologi og Samfund, 1997 == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Faroese people]] [[Category:Handball players]] [[Category:Merchants]] [[Category:1943 births]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Mortensen, Hans}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Tórshavn]] [[Category:Chief executive officers]] [[Category:Businesspeople]]

{{Infobox person | name = | image = Jeff Goodby @ SXSW 2017 (cropped).jpg | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = Goodby at [[South by Southwest]] 2017 | birth_date = <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} for living people supply only the year with {{Birth year and age|YYYY}} unless the exact date is already widely published, as per [[WP:DOB]]. For people who have died, use {{Birth date|YYYY|MM|DD}}. --> | birth_place = | nationality = American | other_names = | occupation = Advertising executive | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Jeff Goodby''' is an American advertising executive. He is among the co-founders and serves as co-chair of [[Goodby, Silverstein & Partners]] in [[San Francisco]]. Goodby is also a director and illustrator whose work has appeared in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' and ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]''.
==Early life==
Jeff Goodby grew up in Rhode Island. He graduated from [[Harvard University]] where he wrote for [[Harvard Lampoon|The Harvard Lampoon]]. Goodby became interested in advertising after not being able to find work in publishing. Goodby fashioned a resume in the likes of a mock encyclopedia entry on himself – written posthumously.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inc.com/magazine/20040701/howididit.html |title=How I Did It: Jeff Goodby, Leading Your Company Article - Inc. Article |publisher=Inc.com |date=2004-07-01 |accessdate=2011-08-13}}</ref> That landed him his first advertising job at [[J. Walter Thompson]] where he met mentor [[Hal Riney]] of Ogilvy & Mather.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clioawards.com/festival/speaker.cfm?speaker_id=2 |title=CLIO Awards |publisher=CLIO Awards |date= |accessdate=2011-08-13}}</ref>
==Career== Goodby, Silverstein & Partners has on multiple occasions won Agency of the Year in Advertising Age<ref>{{cite web|last=Cuneo |first=Alice Z. |url=http://adage.com/article?article_id=123178 |title=From Goodby to Great: How Shop Built a 'Content House' | Print Edition - Advertising Age |publisher=Adage.com |date=2008-01-21 |accessdate=2011-08-13}}</ref> Adweek<ref>{{cite web|last=Parpis |first=Eleftheria |url=http://www.adweek.com/aw/content_display/special-reports/agency-of-the-year/e3i55ff39a0bb8b6b74ef2d80fb85a8ac45 |title=2007 U.S. AOY: Goodby, Silverstein & Partners |publisher=Adweek |date= |accessdate=2011-08-13}}</ref> and Creativity Magazine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://creativity-online.com/news/agency-of-the-year-goodby-silverstein-partners/38987 |title=AGENCY OF THE YEAR: Goodby, Silverstein & Partners - The Editors Of Creativity - From Creativity |publisher=Creativity Online |date=2003-12-08 |accessdate=2011-08-13}}</ref> The [[Museum of Modern Art]] has placed several of the company's ads into permanent rotation, including among others “[[got milk?]]” and the [[Budweiser Frogs|Budweiser Lizards]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sourceecreative.com/news.php?ID=3655 |title=News |publisher=SourceEcreative |date= |accessdate=2011-08-13}}</ref>
Goodby served as the president of the [[Cannes Lions International Advertising Festival|Cannes Advertising Festival]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediawareonline.com/newsletter/cannes.htm |title=Media Trends - The Annual Budget Ritual |publisher=Mediawareonline.com |date=2002-01-22 |accessdate=2011-08-13}}</ref> head judge of the Titanium Jury<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rga.com/news/release/2005/cannes-lions-2005 |title=Full-service interactive, digital advertising agency |publisher=R/GA |date= |accessdate=2011-08-13}}</ref> and chaired judging the ANDYS.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.andyawards.com/|title=Home - ANDY Awards|website=ANDY Awards}}</ref> In 2006, Goodby was inducted into the Advertising Hall of Fame.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oneclub.org/oc/hall_of_fame/good_silver/ |title= Jeff Goodby And Rich Silverstein|accessdate=January 18, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101228065412/http://www.oneclub.org/oc/hall_of_fame/good_silver/ |archivedate=December 28, 2010 }}</ref> Jeff Goodby and his fellow co-chairman [[Rich Silverstein]] were also highlighted in the 2009 documentary, “[[Art & Copy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://artandcopyfilm.com/bios/ |title=Art & Copy Film / Subject Bios |publisher=Artandcopyfilm.com |date= |accessdate=2011-08-13}}</ref>” In 2010, [[Adweek]] named him, along with Rich Silverstein, Executives of the Decade.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bestofthe2000s.com/agency-executives-of-the-decade.html |title=AdweekMedia: Best of the 2000s - Agency Executives of the Decade |publisher=Best of the 2000s |date= |accessdate=2011-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110910100704/http://www.bestofthe2000s.com/agency-executives-of-the-decade.html |archivedate=2011-09-10 |df= }}</ref>
==Philanthropy== Goodby sits on the board of directors of the [[National Audubon Society]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170402131440/http://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20130721/NONPROFITS/307219979/audubon-society-flying-high|title=Audubon Society flying high - Crain's New York Business|date=2 April 2017|publisher=}}</ref>

[[Image:John Carlyle.gif|right|200px|John Carlyle of Alexandria]] '''John Carlyle''' (6 February 1720–October 1780) was a [[Scotland|Scottish]] [[merchant]] who immigrated to [[British Empire|British]] [[Colony of Virginia]] and became a leading landowner and social and political figure in [[Northern Virginia]]. He was a founding trustee and the first overseer of [[Alexandria, Virginia]].
==Biography==
Born in [[Carlisle, Cumbria|Carlisle]], [[Cumbria]], [[England]], Carlyle was the second surviving son of William Carlyle, an apothecary-surgeon, of a landed Scottish family from Dumfrieshire descended from the [[Lord Carlyle of Torthorwald|Lords Carlyle of Torthorwald]] and Rachel Murray of [[Murraythwaite]], Dumfriesshire. He immigrated to Virginia in 1741 as a [[factor (agent)|factor]] (agent) of [[England|English]] merchant William Hicks. He established himself as a merchant at Belhaven, a settlement that had grown up around a tobacco warehouse on the bluff overlooking the [[Potomac River]] that would become [[Alexandria, Virginia]], in 1749.
Carlyle quickly met with financial success and, in 1747, married Sarah Fairfax, cousin of [[Thomas Fairfax, 6th Lord Fairfax of Cameron]], from one of the most influential families in Virginia. From 1751–53, he built his house, now [[Carlyle House]], in Alexandria and he also owned thousands of acres of land throughout Virginia, including three plantations. His business ventures included trading with England and the [[West Indies]], retail operations in Alexandria, a [[foundry]] in the [[Shenandoah Valley]], milling, and operation of a [[forge]]. He also undertook a number of civic and religious positions typical of a man of his status. [[Image:The Carlyle House 1752 (crop).png|thumb|right|200px|The Carlyle House built 1752, in 1909]] [[Image:Carlyle tomb.jpg|thumb|200px|Tomb of John Carlyle]] On 26 January 1754, he was appointed by Virginia's Lieutenant Governor [[Robert Dinwiddie]], major and commissary of the Virginia forces in the [[French and Indian War]]. He was politically well-connected at the time and was friends with future [[President of the United States]] [[George Washington]]. In 1755, Carlyle's house was the initial headquarters for Major-General [[Edward Braddock]] in Virginia during the French and Indian War. The [[Congress of Alexandria]] convened at the house, most likely in the dining room, and here Braddock decided to make an [[Braddock expedition|expedition]] to [[Fort Duquesne]] which would result in his death. He was urged not to undertake the expedition by Washington who was then a volunteer ''[[aide-de-camp]]'' to Braddock.
Following the death of his wife Sarah on 22 January 1761, Carlyle married Sybil West, daughter of prominent Alexandrian Hugh West.
Around 1770, Caryle constructed a plantation house and summer residence in what is now [[Fairlington, Arlington, Virginia]] first called Torthorwald (after his [[Torthorwald|family's ancestral home]] in Scotland) and later changed to Morven (a mythical land of the [[Gaels]] in an [[Ossian]] poem) which stood until 1942. He used this plantation as a stud farm and operated a grist mill on [[Four Mile Run]] above what is now [[Arlandria, Virginia|Arlandria]].
Carlyle died in 1780 and is buried at the [[Old Presbyterian Meeting House]] in Alexandria.
John Carlyle's only son to survive beyond childhood was George William Carlyle, born in 1766. He served in the cavalry (3rd Continental Light Dragoons under Lt. Col. William Washington, a cousin of George Washington) and was killed in [[South Carolina]] in the [[American Revolutionary War]] [[Battle of Eutaw Springs]] on 8 September 1781<ref>Documentary History of the American Revolution, Vol. 3 by Robert W. Gibbes, 1853.</ref> at age 15, less than one year after the death of his father. John Carlyle's grandson through his daughter Sarah Carlyle, [[John Carlyle Herbert]], inherited Carlyle House in 1781. Had George William Carlyle lived, he would have been entitled to the dormant [[baron]]y as [[Lord Carlyle of Torthorwald|Lord Carlyle]], after the death of his first cousin [[Joseph Dacre Carlyle]] who died without a son in 1804.

[https://www.jstor.org/stable/1915700 "The Carlyle Family."] ''William and Mary College Quarterly Historical Magazine''. Vol.18, No.3. (January 1910). pp. 201–212. *Richard Henry Spencer. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/1921070 The Carlyle House and its Associations--Braddock's Headquarters--Here the Colonial Governors met in Council, April, 1755."] ''William and Mary College Quarterly Historical Magazine''. Vol.18, No.1. (July 1909). pp. 1–17.

In November 1999, Jaymont sold the development site to a partnership of [[Cousins Properties|Cousins Properties Inc.]] and Myers Development Company for US$22 million.{{cite news |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/stories/1999/11/15/daily6.html |title=Cousins, Myers close on development site |work=San Francisco Business Times |date=November 17, 1999 |accessdate=November 22, 2013}} Groundbreaking took place in May 2000 and the building was completed in March 2002.{{cite web |url=http://www.myersdevelopment.com/050200.htm |title=Cousins and Myers Commence One Second Street: Major Tenants Signed for New San Francisco Office Tower |publisher=Myers Development Company |date=May 2, 2000 |accessdate=November 22, 2013 |quote=Cousins Properties Incorporated and Myers Development Company today announced the commencement of One Second Street, a 374,000 square foot Class "A" office tower located in the heart of San Francisco's Financial District.}}{{cite web |url=http://www.myersdevelopment.com/ |title=Myers Development Company (Projects > Commercial > KPMG Building) |accessdate=November 22, 2013}} In September 2004, Cousins/Myers sold the building to an affiliate of [[Hines Interests Limited Partnership]] for US$146.4 million.{{cite press release |url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20040921005137/en/CousinsMyers-Partnerships-Sell-San-Francisco-Office-Buildings |title=Cousins/Myers Partnerships Sell San Francisco Office Buildings for $287 Million |publisher=Cousins Properties Incorporated via BUSINESSWIRE |date=September 21, 2004 |accessdate=November 22, 2013}} Like many other buildings in the area, 55 Second Street contains a [[public space]], described by the San Francisco Chronicle as "a big room with hardwood floors, skylights and grand leather chairs, like a private club", which is located on a [[mezzanine]] level.{{Cite web|title = Vibrant center of city’s future a good place to grab lunch|url = http://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/nativeson/article/Vibrant-center-of-city-s-future-a-good-place-to-6419684.php|accessdate = 2015-08-02|website = SF Chronicle|publisher = |last = Nolte|first = Carl|date = 2015-08-01|quote = ... most of the streets are sunny and many have public plazas, an amenity the city requires of potential developers. There are 64 of these public places in private buildings [...] all sandwiched in less than a square city mile. One of the best of these public spaces is at 55 Second St., on a mezzanine up a set of polished stairs. Here is a big room with hardwood floors, skylights and grand leather chairs, like a private club. The public is welcome to sit, read, eat lunch or just hang out.}} == Major tenants == * [[KPMG]] * [[Buchalter]] * [[Intercom (company)]] ==See also== * [[345 Park Avenue]]—KPMG's headquarters in New York City * [[List of tallest buildings in San Francisco]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.hines.com/property/detail.aspx?id=519 KPMG Building] at [[Hines Interests Limited Partnership]] {{Buildings in San Francisco|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Financial District, San Francisco]] [[Category:Hines Interests Limited Partnership]] [[Category:Office buildings completed in 2002]] [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in San Francisco]] [[Category:2002 establishments in California]] [[Category:KPMG]]
