{{Eastern Slavic name|Vladimirovich|Deripaska}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Oleg Deripaska | image = Дерипаска Олег Владимирович.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Deripaska in 2012 | birth_name = Oleg Vladimirovich Deripaska | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1968|1|2}} | birth_place = [[Dzerzhinsk, Russia|Dzerzhinsk]], [[Nizhny Novgorod Oblast]], [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Russian SFSR]], [[Soviet Union]] | occupation = Chairman of Supervisory Board of [[Basic Element (company)|Basic Element Company]] | citizenship = Russia
Cyprus{{cite news|last1=Farolfi|first1=Sara|last2=Harding|first2=Luke|title=EU citizenship for sale as Russian oligarch buys Cypriot passport|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/mar/02/eu-citizenship-for-sale-as-russian-oligarch-oleg-deripaska-buys-cypriot-passport|accessdate=5 March 2018|work=The Guardian|date=2 March 2018|language=en}} | networth = US$3.3 billion (November 2018){{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/oleg-deripaska/|work=[[Forbes]]|last=Rapoza|title= Oleg Deripaska|accessdate=9 April 2018}} | residence = Moscow, Russia | alma_mater = [[Moscow State University]], [[Plekhanov Russian Academy of Economics]] | children = 2 | website = [http://www.basel.ru/en/ Basic Element]
[https://web.archive.org/web/20110721132537/http://www.deripaska.com/ Deripaska.com] | awards = {{plainlist | * [[File:Order of Alexander Nevsky 2010 ribbon.svg|25px]] [[Order of Alexander Nevsky]] * [[File:Orden of Friendship.png|25px]] [[Order of Friendship]] }} }} '''Oleg Vladimirovich Deripaska''' ({{lang-ru|Оле́г Влади́мирович Дерипа́ска}}; born 2 January 1968){{cite web|url=http://www.deripaska.ru|title=Oleg Vladimirovich Deripaska|publisher=deripaska.ru|language=Russian|accessdate=7 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160208151706/http://www.deripaska.ru/|archive-date=8 February 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} is a Russian [[Business oligarch|oligarch]][https://www.ft.com/content/08f230b0-4dfb-11e8-8a8e-22951a2d8493 Oleg Deripaska, Russian oligarch under siege for Putin ties] - Financial Times, 4 May 2018[https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/01/us/politics/deripaska-ohr-steele-fbi.html U.S. Agents Tried To Turn Oligarch Into an Informer] - New York Times, 1 September 2018 and philanthropist.{{failed verification|date=October 2018}} He is the founder of [[Basic Element (company)|Basic Element]], one of Russia's largest industrial groups, and [[Volnoe Delo]], Russia's largest charitable foundation. Until 2018,{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-russia-rusal-deripaska/russian-magnate-deripaska-to-quit-roles-at-his-two-biggest-firms-idUSKCN1G31D3|title=Russian magnate Deripaska to quit roles at his two biggest firms|last=Devitt|first=Polina|work=U.S.|access-date=14 August 2018|language=en-US}} he was the president of [[En+ Group]], a Russian energy-related company, and [[Rusal|United Company Rusal]], the second largest aluminium company in the world.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rusal.ru/en/about/management/|title=Management|publisher=[[Rusal|United Company Rusal]]|accessdate=2 June 2017}} After graduating from [[Moscow State University]] with a degree in physics, Deripaska became a metals broker specialized in trading aluminium before expanding into energy, machinery, financial services and agribusiness. In 2000, Deripaska founded Rusal, the result of a partnership between Sibirsky Aluminium and [[Roman Abramovich]]'s [[Millhouse Capital]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB106443818395367800|title=Aluminum Shake-Up May Loom in Russia|last=Whalen|first=Jeanne|date=25 September 2003|work=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=2 June 2017|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}} In 2007, Rusal merged with SUAL Group and Glencore International AG to form UC Rusal, with Deripaska as chairman.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/aluminium-russia-merger-idUSL2713534620070327|title=RUSAL, SUAL, Glencore complete aluminium merger|date=27 March 2007|agency=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=2 June 2017}} He was once [[List of Russian billionaires|Russia's richest man]], worth $28 billion, but lost a substantial part of his fortune amid the [[Financial crisis of 2007–2008|2007–08 financial crisis]]. As of August 2018, his wealth was estimated by ''[[Forbes]]'' at $3.3 billion. Deripaska is also known for his connection to American political consultant [[Paul Manafort]], who has been convicted on charges of tax fraud, bank fraud and failure to report foreign bank accounts, which stemmed from [[Robert Mueller]]'s [[Special Counsel investigation (2017–present)|investigation]] into [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]]. Deripaska employed Manafort from at least 2005 to 2009.{{cite news|last1=Stone|first1=Peter|title=Trump's new right-hand man has history of controversial clients and deals|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/apr/27/paul-manafort-donald-trump-campaign-past-clients|accessdate=3 June 2017|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=27 April 2016}} As the founder of Volnoe Delo foundation, he is reported to have donated more than $250 million to mostly educational causes. He was married to Polina Yumasheva, step-granddaughter of former Russian President [[Boris Yeltsin]] and daughter of [[Valentin Yumashev]], Yeltsin's son-in-law and close advisor. According to some media reports, they were divorced in 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://news.rambler.ru/other/40543183-zheny-izvestnyh-lyudey-zarabatyvayut-na-restoranah-i-galereyah/|title=Жёны известных людей зарабатывают на ресторанах и галереях|work=Рамблер/новости|access-date=15 August 2018|language=ru-RU}} Deripaska was also granted [[Cypriot citizenship]] in 2017. ==Education and early career== ===Early life=== Deripaska was born in [[Dzerzhinsk, Russia|Dzerzhinsk]], [[Nizhny Novgorod Oblast]], [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Soviet Russia]] and grew up in [[Ust-Labinsk]], [[Krasnodar Krai]]. His parents were from [[Kuban]].{{cite news|title=Олигарх Дерипаска участвовал в приеме парада Кубанского казачьего войска|url=http://yasnonews.ru/news/politika/oligarkh_deripaska_uchastvoval_v_prieme_parada_kubanskogo_kazachego_voyska/|accessdate=25 May 2017|work=Yasno|date=22 April 2017|language=ru}} Deripaska grew up on the family's small farm, where from the age of 5 or 6, he learned how to live off the land from his grandparents,{{cite web|title=Deripaska Rebound From Near-Crash Stares Down Potanin|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2011-02-21/deripaska-rebounding-from-near-disaster-stares-down-potanin-as-metals-soar|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|accessdate=13 January 2016|first=Stephanie|last=Baker}} who primarily raised him after his widowed mother, an engineer, had to leave to find work.{{cite news|last1=Reguly|first1=Eric|title=At home with Russian oligarch Oleg Deripaska|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/careers/careers-leadership/at-home-with-russian-oligarch-oleg-deripaska/article573998/?page=all|accessdate=25 May 2017|work=The Globe and Mail|date=11 February 2011|language=en-ca}} Deripaska credits his grandparents for teaching him the discipline of hard work along with farming. Both his grandfathers fought in the [[Second World War]]; one was killed in battle and buried in a mass grave in [[Austria]], the other returned to Russia after the war ended.{{cite web|title=PROFILE: 'We're waiting for the aluminium industry to do its homework,' Deripaska says |url=http://www.metalbulletin.com/Article/3250360/Search/PROFILE-Were-waiting-for-the-aluminium-industry-to-do-its.html?PageId=196010&Keywords=deripaska&OrderType=1&PageMove=2#axzz3sPgcUxAJ |publisher=metalbulletin.com |accessdate=13 January 2016}} Deripaska's first job was at the Ust-Labinsk plant where his mother worked. At age 11, he became an electrician's apprentice doing maintenance on electrical motors. Deripaska acquired a passion for reading; his favorite authors were [[Mayne Reid]] and [[Jack London]]. Today, Basic Element's headquarters contain walls of books, reflecting Deripaska's lifelong love of reading. His talent for math allowed him to enroll at the physics faculty of Moscow State University in 1985. One year into his studies, he was conscripted into the armed forces and served in the Soviet army's Strategic Missile Forces in the [[Transbaikal Military District|Trans-Baikal area]], Siberia, from 1986–1989. ===Education === In 1993, Deripaska graduated with honors in physics from [[Moscow State University]];{{cite web|title=Basic Element – History|url=http://www.basel.ru/en/history/}} however, the [[Dissolution of the Soviet Union|collapse of the Soviet Union]] greatly eliminated academic funding and made it impossible for him to continue his studies as a [[Theoretical physics|theoretical physicist]]. There were no stipends or grants for students either. "We had no money. It was an urgent and practical question every day. How do I earn money to buy food and keep studying?" he recalls. In 1996, he earned a master's degree from the [[Plekhanov Russian University of Economics|Plekhanov University of Economics]]. ===Early career=== At the age of 25, teaming up with fellow physicists, engineers and rocket scientists, Deripaska set up his first metal trading company, VTK. He adopted a systematic, scientific approach to [[commodity trading]]. "I represented companies that were buying and selling raw materials", Deripaska said. Deripaska undertook export arbitrage, buying metal at low Russian prices and selling it abroad at significantly higher international market prices. Deripaska traded primarily through the Baltic state of [[Estonia]] as the Russian system of export licenses was in disarray. "I started my business at an unusual moment in history. The country in which I was born raised had disappeared, although the new country was not fully formed. The first one gave me an excellent education; the second one gave me the chance of success", Deripaska recalled in an interview with ''[[Metal Bulletin]]''. He used nearly all his arbitrage and trading profits to acquire his initial package of shares in the [[Sayanogorsk]] Aluminium Smelter in [[Southern Siberia]].{{Cite news|title=FACTBOX: Who is Oleg Deripaska?|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-russia-deripaska-profile-idUSTRE51L1IH20090222|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=22 February 2009|accessdate=13 January 2016}} Between 1993 and 1994, Deripaska bought vouchers and shares in Sayanogorsk, and accumulated a 20% stake in the factory, becoming the biggest individual shareholder after the Russian State—to the annoyance of the plant's Communist-era bosses. In 1994, Deripaska became director general of the plant at the age of 26. In 1997, he founded Sibirsky (Siberian) Aluminium Group, which in 2000 merged with [[Roman Abramovich]]'s [[Millhouse Capital]] to create RUSAL.{{Cite web|title=RUSAL battle set for British court|url=http://www.stabroeknews.com/2012/news/world/07/07/rusal-battle-set-for-british-court-2/|work=Stabroek News|date=7 July 2012|accessdate=13 January 2016}} In 2003, businesses led by Deripaska increased their stake in those companies under common management to 75% by acquiring half of the interest managed by Millhouse Capital.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB955986247819859000|title=Russia's Aluminum Barons Form Cartel to Control 10% of Output|author=Jeanne Whalen|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=14 January 2016|issn=0099-9660}} In 2004, the consolidation of RUSAL's ownership by companies related to Deripaska was completed with the acquisition of the remaining 25% equity interest in RUSAL managed by Millhouse Capital.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB106443818395367800|title=Aluminum Shake-Up May Loom in Russia|author=Jeanne Whalen|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=14 January 2016|issn=0099-9660}} ===Business growth=== [[RUSAL]] went on to become the largest aluminium producer in the world, until the [[China Hongqiao Group]] surpassed it in 2015. In 2010, under Deripaska's leadership, Rusal became the first Russian company to be listed on the [[Hong Kong Stock Exchange]]. Beyond metals, which remain at the core of his diversified industrial holding, Deripaska has acquired stakes in a wide range of companies in various sectors, including energy, manufacturing, commercial vehicles, auto components, financial and insurance services,{{Cite web|title=Sberbank of Russia: Basic Element, Sberbank and Changi Airports International sign Memorandum of Understanding for Airport Business Partnership|url= http://data.sberbank.ru/en/press_center/all/index.php?id114=11014378|website=data.sberbank.ru|accessdate=13 January 2016}} leasing businesses, construction,{{Cite web|title=Строительство|url=http://www.basel.ru/building-realty/Construction/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150318192513/http://www.basel.ru/building-realty/construction/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=18 March 2015|website=www.basel.ru|accessdate=13 January 2016}} aviation, and agriculture. Among his assets are a Siberian power company EuroSibEnergo,[http://www.eurosib.ru/eng/ EuroSibEnergo company website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090511060730/http://www.eurosib.ru/eng/ |date=11 May 2009 }} that is Russia's biggest private energy company; [[Ingosstrakh]], one of Russia's largest insurance companies; [[GAZ Group]], a producer of cars, trucks and buses, agricultural business (Kuban Agro Holding);{{cite web|url=http://www.ahkuban.ru|title=Agroholding Kuban website|publisher=ahkuban.ru|accessdate=7 November 2012}}{{Cite web|title=Агрохолдинг "Кубань" и производитель семян Maisadour создают СП в России|url=http://www.vedomosti.ru/business/articles/2015/11/30/618839-kuban-maisadour-sp|website = www.vedomosti.ru|accessdate=13 January 2016}} and transport companies, such as a cluster of airports in the [[Krasnodar (region)|Krasnodar region]], including [[Sochi]] and Krasnodar.{{vague|reason= K{{cite web|url=http://www.basel.aero|title=Basel Aero website|publisher=basel.aero|accessdate=7 November 2012}} All these assets form part of the diversified investment and industrial group Basic Element.{{cite web|url=http://www.basel.ru/en/regions|title=Basic Element website|date=1 January 2008|publisher=Basel.ru|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723091302/http://www.basel.ru/en/regions/|archivedate=23 July 2011|deadurl=yes|accessdate=14 May 2011|df=dmy-all}} Basic Element built several Olympic facilities for [[2014 Winter Olympics]] in [[Sochi]], including the Coastal Olympic Village, Imeretisnkiy sea port, Doubler of Kurortny Avenue in Sochi, renovation of the Sochi International Airport. The total investments account for over $1.4 billion.{{Cite web|title=Rich Russians Sparring With Putin Over $48 Billion Olympics Bet|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-11-26/rich-russians-sparring-with-putin-over-48-billion-olympics-bet|work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|accessdate=14 January 2016|first=Stephanie| last=Baker| first2=Ilya|last2=Arkhipov}} ==Later business career== ===Basic Element=== Deripaska is the sole owner and Chairman of Supervisory Board of [[Basic Element (company)|Basic Element]], a diversified investment group established in 1997 which has been managing his investments in the following six sectors: [[Energy (society)|energy]], metals and mining, machinery, [[financial services]], agriculture, construction, and aviation. The major investments under Basic Element management included stakes in [[United Company RUSAL]]{{cite web|url=http://www.rusal.ru/en/Default.aspx|title=RUSAL company website|publisher=Rusal.ru|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110409195407/http://www.rusal.ru/en/Default.aspx|archivedate=9 April 2011|deadurl=yes|accessdate=14 May 2011|df=dmy-all}} (the world's largest aluminium and alumina producer), [[GAZ Group]] (an [[Automotive industry|automotive company]]), [[Aviakor|Aviakor aircraft manufacturer]], EuroSibEnergo (ЕвроСибЭнерго (an [[energy supply]] company) Glavmosstroy (Главмосстрой) (a construction company){{cite web|url=http://www.glavmosstroy.ru/eindex.htm|title=Glavmosstroy website|publisher=Glavmosstroy.ru|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907045059/http://www.glavmosstroy.ru/eindex.htm|archivedate=7 September 2011|deadurl=yes|accessdate=14 May 2011|df=dmy-all}} Kuban Agroholding (an agricultural company) and Basel Aero (an aviation business comprising the three largest airports in the Krasnodar territory, and a joint venture with Changi Airports International). Basic Element has been managing Oleg Deripaska's investments into companies in Russia, the [[Commonwealth of Independent States|CIS]] countries, Africa, Australia, Asia, Europe and Latin America, which employ as many as 250,000 people. === EN+ Group === The group was formed in 2006, with Oleg Deripaska as President and controlling shareholder.{{Cite web|url=http://eng.enplus.ru/about/management/|title=En+ - ведущая российская индустриальная группа, лидер в металлургии, энергетике и горнорудной промышленности|website=eng.enplus.ru|accessdate=2 June 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170728080934/http://eng.enplus.ru/about/management/|archive-date=28 July 2017|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} The EN+ Group is a diversified mining, metals and energy groups. It owns a majority stake in UC Rusal (48.13%{{Cite web|url=http://www.rusal.ru/en/about/facts/|title=Facts and Figures|website=www.rusal.ru|accessdate=2 June 2017}}) and in EuroSibEnergo. EN+ also holds interests in SMR, one of the world's largest [[ferromolybdenum]] producers.  In 2017, it reported adjusted core earnings of $2.3 billion, on revenues totaling $9.8 billion.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/russia-en-idUSL5N1H72UO|title=Russian tycoon Deripaska's En+ says 2016 core earnings $2.3 bln|date=18 April 2017|agency=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=2 June 2017}} In November 2017 En+ listed on the London Stock Exchange. === Metals and mining === ====RUSAL==== [[Rusal|United Company RUSAL]] is the world's second largest aluminium company. It was the largest until it was overtaken by [[China Hongqiao Group]] in 2015. UC RUSAL accounts for almost 7% of the world's primary aluminium output and 7% of the world's alumina production. The company employs over 63 000 in 20 countries on five continents. In order to ensure a stable supply of alumina to its smelters, several mergers and acquisitions were accomplished by RUSAL under Deripaska's guidance. At the beginning of the 2000s, RUSAL acquired bauxite mines in [[Guinea]], a country with the world's largest bauxite reserves. Subsequently, RUSAL acquired a stake in an alumina refinery in [[Australia]]. At Deripaska's behest, in 2007, RUSAL, [[SUAL Group]], one of the world's top 10 aluminum producers; and [[Glencore|Glencore International AG]], the Swiss natural resources group, merged their assets to form United Company RUSAL, the world's largest aluminum and alumina producer.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-russia-deripaska-profile-idUSTRE51L1IH20090222|title=FACTBOX: Who is Oleg Deripaska?|date=22 February 2009|accessdate=14 January 2016|agency=Reuters}} After the merger with [[Glencore]], bauxite and alumina assets in [[Jamaica]], Italy and Ireland were added to RUSAL's portfolio. These transactions converted RUSAL from a company with few supplies of the raw material bauxite into a vertically integrated corporation.{{cite web|title=Без партнеров|url=http://www.vedomosti.ru/newspaper/articles/2004/10/18/bez-partnerov|publisher=vedomosti.ru|accessdate=14 January 2016}} In parallel, Deripaska invested significantly in the operational improvement of smelters inside Russia. He said, "We consolidated the industry, and located bauxites that do not exist in Russia. We established the company that became the leader of industry in less than twelve years. But to become the number one alumimium producer in the world, we had to improve our operations practice. To apply the best practices in the world, we looked at Toyota, which had utilized a precise, deep and well thought-through process for almost thirty years of operations."{{cite web|url=http://www.rusal.ru/upload/uf/573/PROSPECTUS.pdf|title=United Company RUSAL Limited|publisher=RUSAL|accessdate=3 June 2017}} Deripaska himself has been an active supporter Japanese production efficiencies made popular by the "[[The Toyota Way|Toyota Way]]." RUSAL smelters have adopted the concept of ''[[kaizen]]'', which means continuous improvement and involves training workers in standardized production techniques. "It's important to change both the company’s mind set and reporting lines," Deripaska said. "Instead of top-down management, you should understand everything is in the hands of your operator and empower that operator to drive efficiencies and improvements directly on the factory floor." Under Deripaska's leadership, RUSAL constructed and commissioned Khakas aluminium smelter outside of Sayanogorsk in Russian Siberia. The Khakas facility was the first aluminium smelter built in post-Soviet Russia (since 1985). The smelter, with an annual capacity of 300,000 tonnes, is currently one of the most technologically advanced in the world{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/business/2006/oct/22/theobserver.observerbusiness9|title=Simon Caulkin: The world's most modern plant - and it's in Siberia|last=Caulkin|first=Simon|date=22 October 2006|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=16 August 2018}}. The company also undertook large-scale modernization projects at a number of its facilities, including the Bratsk, Krasnoyarsk and Irkutsk aluminium smelters.{{cite web|title=HKUST IAS - UC RUSAL President's Forum|url=http://ias.ust.hk/ucrusal/2010/transcript.html|publisher=ias.ust.hk|accessdate=14 January 2016}} In the middle of the financial crisis, Deripaska returned in 2009 to RUSAL as CEO to lead the company through the debt restructuring process. "I worked 16-hour days. We were in default, although none of the parties involved wanted to call it default." As part of contingency measures, Deripaska cut costs at RUSAL by 25% in 2009. By December 2009, Deripaska reached a final agreement with over 70 Russian and international lenders to refinance US$17 billion of debt. In 2017, Rusal issued two [[Eurobond]]s to finance its debts. The first one, worth $600 million, was issued in February{{Cite news|url= http://aluminiuminsider.com/rusal-prices-initial-eurobond |title=Rusal Prices Initial Eurobond |date=30 January 2017|work=Aluminium Insider| accessdate =2 June 2017}}, followed by the second one in April, worth $500 million.{{Cite web|url= https://www.ft.com/content/1084218c-2cdc-355b-a52f-7887fb4aea59|title=Rusal profit amid rebound in aluminium prices|work =Financial Times |accessdate=2 June 2017}} Also in February, plans were announced to sell 10 billion yuan worth of seven-year onshore bonds to finance purchases in China. This made Rusal the first foreign company to offer [[panda bonds]] on the [[Shanghai Stock Exchange]].{{Cite news |url= http://www.scmp.com/business/companies/article/2069488/aluminium-giant-rusal-plans-10-billion-yuan-panda-bond-issue|title=Rusal plans 10 billion yuan panda bond issue in Shanghai|work=South China Morning Post|date=9 February 2017|accessdate=2 June 2017}} The company also agreed on a pre-export finance mechanism with international lenders worth $1.7 billion for debt refinancing.{{Cite news|url=http://aluminiuminsider.com/rusal-negotiates-us1-7-bn-pxf-debt-facility |title=Rusal Negotiates US$1.7 BN PXF Debt Facility |date=26 May 2017|work=Aluminium Insider|accessdate=2 June 2017}} In 2013, Deripaska was awarded the "Aluminium Industry Ambassador Award" in the ''[[Metal Bulletin]]'' Awards for Excellence for his "great influence within the global aluminium industry and the wider market".{{cite web|title=Winners of Metal Bulletin's awards for aluminium excellence 2013|url=http://www.metalbulletin.com/Article/3256866/Search/Winners-of-Metal-Bulletins-awards-for-aluminium-excellence.html|work=[[Metal Bulletin]]|accessdate=14 January 2016}} Deripaska stepped down from RUSAL in May 2018 the day after seven board members and the chief executive resigned. The move was part of an effort to get U.S. sanctions removed from the company.{{cite web|title=Sanctioned Tycoon Deripaska Resigns as Director of His Firm Rusal|url=https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2018/05/25/business/25reuters-usa-russia-sanctions-rusal.html|website=[[The New York Times]]|date=25 May 2018|access-date=27 May 2018|agency=Reuters|last1=Devitt|first1=Polina|last2=Voronova|first2=Tatiana|last3=Korsunskaya|first3=Darya|last4=Lowe|first4=Christian|editor-last=Anantharaman|editor-first=Muralikumar}} ===Energy=== ==== EuroSibEnergo ==== Oleg Deripaska owns a 100% stake in EuroSibEnergo, the world's largest private [[hydrogeneration]] company and the largest private power company in Russia.{{Cite web|title=EuroSibEnergo (Russia): Global Sustainable Electricity Partnership|url=http://www.globalelectricity.org/en/index.jsp?p=324|website=www.globalelectricity.org|accessdate=13 January 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160207221639/http://www.globalelectricity.org/en/index.jsp?p=324|archive-date=7 February 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} It controls and manages 18 power plants with a combined installed energy capacity of 19.5 GW, including 15 GW provided by hydrogeneration. The company produces approximately 9% of all electricity in [[Russia]] and is also the leader in the Siberian energy market, with a market share totaling 41%. Some of EuroSibEnergo's key clients include the largest aluminum plants in Russia. The company owns large fuel resources, which satisfy over 85% of the coal needs of its thermal power and boiler plants. Its coal reserves amount to 1.26 billion tons, with annual coal production exceeding 12 million tons. Deripaska's En+ Group, of which EuroSibEnergo is a subsidiary, is investing in a joint venture with China's largest [[hydroelectric power]] generation company [[China Yangtze Power]] Co to build new power plants in Siberia, primarily hydroelectric ones, with a total capacity of up to 10 GWt.{{Cite web| title = China Three Gorges, En+ eye projects in Russia|url=http://www.chinadailyasia.com/business/2015-10/30/content_15337032.html|work=[[China Daily Asia]]|date=30 October 2015|accessdate=13 January 2016}} ===Machinery=== ====Russian Machines==== Russian Machines corporation was established in 2005 and unites Oleg Deripaska's machine building assets. It comprises industrial and engineering assets in the following industries: automotive OEM (GAZ Group), automotive components (RM-Systems), rail industry (RM Rail), aircraft OEM (Aviacor), road construction (RM-Terex) and agricultural machinery (AGCO-RM).{{Cite web|title=GAZ Group: Private Company Information |url= https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapid=8954451|work=[[Businessweek]]|accessdate=13 January 2016}} Russian Machines Corporation manages 24 facilities located across 12 regions in Russia. ====GAZ Group==== In 2000, Deripaska started acquiring machine building assets. His first acquisition was [[Nizhny Novgorod]]-based Gorkovsky Automobile Plant (GAZ), which was previously a government-run company. In 2005, [[GAZ Group]] was established by combining the businessman's machine building assets.{{Cite web|title=Russian GAZ Starts Chrysler Sebring Based Siber Production|url=http://www.carscoops.com/2008/07/russian-gaz-starts-chrysler-sebring.html|work=CarScoops|accessdate=13 January 2016|date=28 July 2008}} The Russian automotive conglomerate, GAZ Group, comprises 18 manufacturing facilities in eight regions of Russia, as well as sales and service organizations. GAZ Group produces light and medium commercial vehicles, heavy trucks, buses, cars, road construction equipment, power units, and automotive components. ====Airports==== Basel Aero, a joint venture between Changi Airports International, Basic Element and Sberbank of Russia, is a company-operator the [[Sochi International Airport|Sochi]], [[Krasnodar International Airport|Krasnodar]] and [[Anapa Airport|Anapa airports]].{{Cite web|title=Sochi airport prepares for Winter Olympics - Airport World Magazine|url=http://www.airport-world.com/news/general-news/2923-sochi-airport-prepares-for-winter-olympics.html|website=www.airport-world.com|accessdate=13 January 2016}} These airports handle more than 7% of the total passenger flow in Russia.{{Cite web|title=Behind the scenes as Sochi Airport warms up for the 2014 Winter Olympic Games|url=http://www.airport-technology.com/features/featuresochi-airport-winter-olympic-games-technology-4160035/|website=Airport Technology |accessdate=13 January 2016}} Sochi International Airport was the main gateway to Sochi [[2014 Winter Olympics]] and successfully serviced the guests and participants of the Games. In October 2014, Sochi was granted [[open skies]] status, meaning that any foreign carrier may pick up and drop off passengers and cargo with no restrictions on aircraft type, frequency, and regardless of interstate agreements.{{Cite web|title=Sochi International Airport: Russia under wide Open Skies|url=http://www.basel.ru/en/in_focus/baselaero_23_03_2015/|work=basel.ru|accessdate=13 January 2016|date=23 March 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160208170115/http://www.basel.ru/en/in_focus/baselaero_23_03_2015/|archive-date=8 February 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ===Financial services=== Deripaska personally holds 10% of [[Ingosstrakh]]'s ordinary shares. The company is a leading insurer of complex risks such as [[Marine insurance|insurance]] for ship owners, ship hull insurance, insurance against aviation and space-related risks, and insurance of transportation companies. Ingosstrakh has 83 branches in Russia and the company's offices operate in 220 Russian towns and cities.{{Cite web|title=Deripaska Insurer's Volkov Says Ingosstrakh to Lease Out Planes|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2010-11-22/deripaska-insurer-s-volkov-says-ingosstrakh-to-lease-out-planes| work =Bloomberg |accessdate=13 January 2016|first=Ilya|last=Khrennikov|date=22 November 2010}} ===Agribusiness=== Oleg Deripaska fully owns Kuban Agroholding, a massive [[agribusiness]] in southern Russia. The company integrates two dairy farms, а 16,000 pig capacity breeding complex, three [[Grain elevator|elevators]] with non-recurrent grain storage capacity of more than 270,000 tonnes, three-seed plants, a sugar factory and the Sunrise horse breeding farm, specializing in the breeding of English [[thoroughbred]] horses. It is one of the top-20 largest agribusinesses and top-5 most efficient land users in Russia.{{Cite journal|title=Russia's Kuban Agroholding launches slaughterhouses, hog farm| url=http://issuu.com/farmingmonthly/docs/february_2015_farming_monthly_natio/12?e=15147366/11395275|work=Farming Monthly|date=February 2015|accessdate=13 January 2016}} Kuban Agroholding is one of the few agrocompanies in Russia involved in [[embryo transfer]] technology that allows for the reproduction of high-yielding milk cows out of less productive recipients.{{Cite web|title=Interview: R&D and innovation are key in race to boost Russia's farm output|url=https://www.agra-net.com/agra/agra-europe/analysis/interview-rd-and-innovation-are-key-in-race-to-boost-russia-s-farm-output-467790.htm|work=Agra-net.com|accessdate=13 January 2016}} The company has gained significant media attention about its corn-seeding program, deploying several dozen corn brands selected by its genetic specialists. === Other roles === In 2004, Deripaska was appointed by the [[President of Russia]] to represent the country in the [[Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation]] [[Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation#APEC Business Advisory Council|Business Advisory Council]] (ABAC). He has been Chairman of ABAC Russia since 2007. Deripaska is the vice president of the [[Russian Union of Industrialists and Entrepreneurs]], chairman of the executive board of the Russian national committee of the [[International Chamber of Commerce]] and a member of the Competitiveness and Entrepreneurship Council, an agency of the Russian government.[http://www.deripaska.com/about-oleg-deripaska/biography Oleg Deripaska biodata] {{webarchive|url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110721132612/http://www.deripaska.com/about-oleg-deripaska/biography|date=21 July 2011}}. Retrieved 12 May 2012. He has been a permanent participant at [[World Economic Forum]] sessions since 2007, when RUSAL became a WEF strategic partner.{{Cite web|title=Oleg V. Deripaska|url=http://www.weforum.org/contributors/oleg-v-deripaska|publisher=[[World Economic Forum]]|accessdate=13 January 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150404232416/http://www.weforum.org/contributors/oleg-v-deripaska|archive-date=4 April 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} In May 2007, [[Magna International]] chairman [[Frank Stronach]] announced that Deripaska was becoming a strategic partner in Magna.{{Cite web|url = http://www.reportonbusiness.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20070510.wmagna10/BNStory/robNews/home|title = Russian billionaire buying Magna stake|date = 10 May 2007|work = The Globe and Mail |last = Keenan|first = Greg}} Deripaska is also a member of the International Council at [[Harvard University]]'s [[Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.belfercenter.org/person/oleg-deripaska|title=Oleg Deripaska|publisher=Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs|accessdate=4 May 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170405171539/https://www.belfercenter.org/person/oleg-deripaska|archivedate=5 April 2017|df=dmy-all}} Deripaska personally initiated construction of the Centre for Epidemic and Microbiological Research and Treatment in the Guinean [[Kindia Region|Kindia]] province. The Centre was designed and constructed by [[United Company RUSAL|RUSAL]] specialists with the assistance of [[Rospotrebnadzor]] scientists (RUSAL has invested $10 million).{{Cite web|url=http://africatimes.com/2017/05/22/ebola-2-0-lessons-learned-in-2014-may-not-suffice/|title=Ebola 2.0 – Lessons Learned in 2014 May Not Suffice|date=22 May 2017|website=Africa Times|accessdate=25 May 2017}} He sits on the board of trustees of the School of Business Administration, the School of Public Administration, and the School of Economics at [[Moscow State University]] as well as the School of Business Administration at [[St. Petersburg State University]]. Deripaska is a co-founder of the National Science Support Foundation and the National Medicine Fund. In 1999, he was awarded the [[Order of Friendship]], a state award of the [[Russian Federation]]. He was named businessman of the year in 1999, 2006, and 2007 by ''[[Vedomosti]]'', a Russian business daily. Deripaska also sits on the board of trustees of the [[Bolshoi Theatre]], and has financed [[ballet]] performances like ''[[Flames of Paris]]'', ''[[La Sylphide]]'', and ''[[Paquita]]'' as well as [[opera]]s like ''[[The Legend of the Invisible City of Kitezh and the Maiden Fevroniya]]'', ''[[Carmen]]'', and ''[[Wozzeck]]''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.forbes.ru/profile/oleg-deripaska|title=Олег Дерипаска|work=Forbes Russia|accessdate=13 January 2016}} ==Philanthropy== {{Advert section|date=February 2018}} ===Volnoe Delo=== In 1998, Deripaska established [[Volnoe Delo]], Russia's largest private charitable foundation.{{Cite news|url=https://www.europeanceo.com/profiles/oleg-deripaska-and-the-russian-aluminium-wars/|title=Oleg Deripaska and the Russian aluminium wars|access-date=25 May 2018|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=http://volnoe-delo.ru/en/|title=Volnoe Delo Foundation|website=volnoe-delo.ru|language=ru|access-date=25 May 2018}}[http://www.volnoe-delo.ru (20 April 2009): The Volnoe Delo Fund acknowledged as the largest contributor] {{ru icon}} The fund supports over 400{{cn|date=February 2018}} initiatives across Russia aimed at developing education and science, preserving spiritual and cultural heritage, and improving standards in public health.[http://www.volnoe-delo.ru/ Volnoe Delo Fund website] {{ru icon}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.heritagedaily.com/2016/08/darius-i-stele-found-in-ancient-town-of-phanagoria-in-russia/112378|title=Darius I stele found in ancient town of Phanagoria in Russia - HeritageDaily - Heritage & Archaeology News|website=www.heritagedaily.com|language=en-US|access-date=25 May 2018}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/billionaire-sochi-stray-dogs_n_4767912?guccounter=1|title=Billionaire Saves Sochi Stray Dogs!|date=11 February 2014|work=HuffPost UK|access-date=25 May 2018|language=en-GB}} It helps children, old people, talented youths, teachers, eminent scientists and other participants of the programs. Since 1998, Oleg Deripaska has invested more than [[Russian ruble|RUB]]10.6 billion{{cn|date=February 2018}} in more than 500 charity programs in 50 regions of Russia.{{Cite web|url=http://volnoe-delo.ru/en/|title=Volnoe Delo Foundation|website=volnoe-delo.ru|accessdate=13 January 2016}}{{additional citation|date=February 2018}} Volnoe Delo has supported research activities in the 2,550-year-old city of [[Phanagoria]] since 2004. More than $10 million has been allocated to Phanagoria fieldwork over the past 14 years.{{Cite news|url=https://popular-archaeology.com/article/darius-i-stele-found-in-ancient-town-of-phanagoria-in-russia/|title=Popular Archeology - Darius I stele found in ancient town of Phanagoria in Russia|work=Popular Archeology|access-date=25 May 2018|language=en-US}} Today, Phanagoria is one of the best-equipped archeological expeditions in Russia and has its own scientific and cultural center, cutting edge equipment and technology for above-ground and underwater excavation as well as a large team of specialists involved in the excavation process.{{Cite web|url=http://popular-archaeology.com/issue/06052014/article/ancient-naval-ram-found-in-phanagoria-reveals-history-of-popular-unrest-in-63-b-c|title=Ancient naval ram found in Phanagoria reveals history of popular unrest in 63 B.C.|work=Popular Archeology|accessdate=13 January 2016}} In 2014, Volnoe Delo foundation launched a programme on students' early career guidance and professional training—JuniorSkills.{{Cite web|url=http://volnoe-delo.ru/en/events/news/junior-skills/|title=Junior Skills|website=volnoe-delo.ru|accessdate=13 January 2016}} The first, pilot, championship on professional skills, JuniorSkills Hi-Tech, was held in the Urals city of [[Yekaterinburg]] in 2014, part of the nationwide championship on cross-industry blue-collar professions in high-tech WorldSkills. ===Climate change === Deripaska is one of the 16 global business leaders who drafted CEO Climate Policy Recommendations to [[G8]] Leaders, a document outlining the international business community's proposals to tackle [[global warming]]. The proposals were signed by more than 100 of the world's leading corporations and handed to the [[Prime Minister of Japan]] [[Yasuo Fukuda]] on 20 June 2008. The G8 leaders discussed the recommendations during the summit in Japan on 7–9 July 2008. The process was coordinated by the [[World Economic Forum]] in collaboration with the [[World Business Council for Sustainable Development]].{{cite web|url=http://www.weforum.org/en/initiatives/ghg/index.htm|title=World Economic Forum; Climate Change; CEO Climate Policy Recommendations to G8 Leaders|publisher=World Economic Forum|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101213183842/http://www.weforum.org/en/initiatives/ghg/index.htm|archivedate=13 December 2010|deadurl=yes|accessdate=14 May 2011|df=dmy-all}}
[http://www.basel.ru/en/media/news/200807/news_07_07_2008/ Expert magazine; "Zero Waste"; interview] {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Deripaska actively advocates cutting the global carbon footprint and calls for the creation of an enforcement mechanism with consequences for countries that do not reduce carbon-intensive emissions, such as those produced by coal-fired powerplants.{{Cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/b72f19fe-7432-11e5-a129-3fcc4f641d98.html|title=Deripaska warns about competitive risks from Paris climate deal|last=Sanderson|first=Henry|date=18 October 2015|work=Financial Times|accessdate=13 January 2016|last2=Clark|first2=Pilita|issn=0307-1766}} He also remains a strong advocate of a legally binding climate change deal, but has publicly voiced concern about the potential competitive impact of a [[Paris climate agreement]] and also about the absence of binding measures to curb each country's emissions in the near future. "Everyone is in favour; we just need to have more or less fair regulation. There shouldn't be any pockets where people can cheat the system. People shouldn't agree on something that creates another Kyoto protocol that creates nice polished statements", he told the ''Financial Times'' in January 2016. ===Other activities=== In February 2014, Deripaska financed the construction of makeshift kennels to house stray dogs that had been abandoned by construction workers after completing work on the [[Sochi Olympic Stadium|Sochi Olympic Village]]. Officials said the number of strays exceeded 2,000 and the animals presented a risk of [[rabies]], so they contracted out their extermination. Many of these dogs were saved and more were re-homed in a global adoption program that Deripaska created.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/sochi-olympic-parks-condemned-stray-dogs-saved-by-russian-billionaire-9118727.html|title=Sochi Olympic Park's condemned stray dogs 'saved by Russian billionaire'|last=Withnall|first=Adam|date=10 February 2014|work=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=10 February 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6NIpi8tqF?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/sochi-olympic-parks-condemned-stray-dogs-saved-by-russian-billionaire-9118727.html|archivedate=11 February 2014|deadurl=yes|location=London|df=dmy}} ==Assisted FBI with Rescue of Levinson== Between mid-2008 and 2009, Deripaska helped the then-FBI Director [[Robert Mueller]] rescue a former FBI-agent [[Robert Levinson]], who disappeared in 2007 while working for the CIA in Iran. The then-FBI deputy director [[Andrew McCabe]] played key role in courting Deripaska. Agents secretly met Deripaska in hotels in Paris, Vienna, Budapest, Hungary, and Washington, convincing him to spend millions of his own dollars funding the FBI-supervised operation to Levinson. His participation was crucial, as he had close business ties in Iran, and because of economic sanctions imposed on Iran and other laws made it illegal for the FBI or any US citizen to spend any money in Iran. Deripaska's lawyer said he spent $25 million on a private search-and-rescue team that worked with Iranian contacts while monitored by the FBI. Deripaska managed to arrange the release of Levinson, but the U.S. State Department, then under [[Hillary Clinton]], blocked a deal for Levinson's return from going through. Robyn Gritz, the retired agent who supervised the Levinson case in 2009, said: "We tried to turn over every stone we could to rescue Bob, but every time we started to get close, the State Department seemed to always get in the way". “We were told at one point that the terms of Levinson’s release had been agreed to by Iran and the U.S. and included a statement by then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton pointing a finger away from Iran. At the last minute, Secretary Clinton decided not to make the agreed-on statement.” The operation was ended in 2011, because FBI officials were concerned that Deripaska's Iranian contacts couldn't deliver with all the U.S. infighting. The FBI rewarded Deripaska for his help.{{cite news |url=http://thehill.com/opinion/white-house/387625-mueller-may-have-a-conflict-and-it-leads-directly-to-a-russian-oligarch |title=Mueller may have a conflict — and it leads directly to a Russian oligarch |publisher=''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'' |first=John |last=Solomon |date=14 May 2018}}{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/14/world/middleeast/a-disappearing-american-spy-and-the-cia.html |title=A Disappearing Spy, and a Scandal at the C.I.A. |publisher=''The New York Times'' |first=Barry |last=Meier |date=13 December 2013}} == FBI recruitment attempt == According to anonymous sources cited by the 1 September 2018 [[New York Times]]′s report, Deripaska was twice approached by the U.S. government officials, including [[Bruce Ohr]], as part of the U.S. government wider FBI–led recruitment effort to obtain informers in the circle close to [[Vladimir Putin]]: in September 2015 and in September 2016.{{cite news |last1=Vogel |first1=Kenneth P. |last2=Rosenberg |first2=Matthew |title=Agents Tried to Flip Russian Oligarchs. The Fallout Spread to Trump. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/01/us/politics/deripaska-ohr-steele-fbi.html |accessdate=2 September 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=1 September 2018 |language=en}} Ohr, then a [[United States Department of Justice]] official, was reported to have been in contact with the former employee of the [[British secret service]] MI6 [[Christopher Steele]], who later compiled the incriminating [[Trump dossier|dossiers]] on [[Donald Trump]], and discussed cultivating Deripaska, among others. In September 2015, Ohr and Steele met with Deripaska to discuss "connections between Russian organized crime and Mr. Putin’s government, as well as other issues, according to a person familiar with the events." Deripaska laughed them off and did not agree to a second meeting.{{cite news |url=https://www.zeit.de/news/2018-09/02/bericht-us-ermittler-wollten-oligarchen-deripaska-als-informanten-gewinnen-20180902-doc-18s9cd |title=Bericht: US-Ermittler wollten Oligarchen Deripaska als Informanten gewinnen |publisher=''[[Die Zeit]]'' |date=2 September 2018 |lang=de}}{{cite news |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/report-us-investigators-probing-trump-sought-to-cultivate-russian-oligarchs/ |title=Report: US investigators probing Trump sought to cultivate Russian oligarchs |publisher=''[[The Times of Israel]]'' |date=3 September 2018}} Nevertheless, F.B.I. agents showed up unannounced at Deripaska's door in New York in September 2016. The attempts to turn Deripaska into an informant undertaken between 2014 and 2016 were unsuccessful, Deripaska notified the Russian authorities of the US efforts to recruit him. In September 2018, Russia's government accused the US of meddling in the country's affairs by attempting to recruit Russian citizens as agents for American security services.{{cite news |url=https://www.ft.com/content/57cbf8e4-af6f-11e8-8d14-6f049d06439c |title=Russia says US spy agencies attempting to interfere in its affairs |publisher=''Financial Times'' {{subscription required}} |first=Henry |last=Foy |date=3 September 2018}} ==Controversies== ===Cherney lawsuit=== [[Michael Cherney]] brought legal action against Deripaska in the [[Commercial Court (England and Wales)|Commercial Court]] of the [[High Court]] in London.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/the-worlds-richest-russian-is-sued-for-3bn-in-london-437814.html|title=The world's richest Russian is sued for $3bn in London|work=The Independent|location=UK|date=25 February 2007|accessdate=14 May 2011|first=Andrew|last=Osborn}} Cherney sought a declaration that he was the beneficial owner of 20% of [[RUSAL]] stock which, he claimed, Deripaska held in trust for him. The claim was denied. On 3 May 2007, Justice Langley ruled that Deripaska had not been properly [[service of process|served]], and that the court had no [[jurisdiction]] to try the claim as Deripaska did not live in England or Wales.{{cite web|url=http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/Comm/2007/965.html|title=''Cherney v Deripaska'', 2007 EWHC 965 (Comm)|publisher=Bailii.org|accessdate=14 May 2011}} On 3 July 2008, Justice Christopher Clarke ruled that the case should be tried in England, although "the natural forum for this litigation is Russia", because, he held, "risks inherent in a trial in Russia...are sufficient to make England the forum in which the case can most suitably be tried in the interest of both parties and the ends of justice".{{cite web|url=http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/Comm/2008/1530.html|title=''Cherney v Deripaska'', 2008 EWHC 1530 (Comm)|publisher=Bailii.org|accessdate=14 May 2011}} On 22 July 2008, he granted Deripaska leave to appeal. The Court of Appeal of England and Wales refused the appeal on 31 July 2009.{{cite web|url= http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWCA/Civ/2009/849.html|title=Deripaska v Cherney, 2009 EWCA Civ 849|publisher=Bailii.org|accessdate=14 May 2011}} At a June 2011 case management conference, the judge deferred a decision on whether Cherney would be allowed to give evidence by video link from Israel rather than appear in person. An outstanding arrest warrant issued by [[Interpol]] meant that the British would detain him if he travelled to the UK.Paul, Jonny. (23 June 2011) [http://www.jpost.com/International/Article.aspx?id=226187&R=R4 "British High Court to decide: Can Cherney testify by video?"] ''The Jerusalem Post''. 23 June 2011. Retrieved 12 May 2012.[http://www.interpol.int/public/Data/Wanted/Notices/Data/2009/42/2009_21842.asp "Wanted: Cherney, Michael"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot|fix-attempted=yes}}. [[Interpol]], (14 October 2010) In late July 2011, the High Court ruled to allow Cherney to give evidence at the trial by video link from Israel, and also set trial for April 2012.{{cite news |url =http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23973334-the-gangster-a-billionaire-friend-of-mandelson-and-a-pound-23bn-row.do |title=The 'gangster', a billionaire friend of Mandelson and a £2.3bn row|work=Evening Standard|first=Paul|last=Cheston|date=28 July 2011|accessdate=8 August 2011| deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222031121/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23973334-the-gangster-a-billionaire-friend-of-mandelson-and-a-pound-23bn-row.do|archivedate=22 February 2012|df=dmy}} Deripaska denied that Cherney was owed any stake in RUSAL, and asserted payments made to Cherney had been for unavoidable "protection" at a time when violence was sweeping the region and posed an existential threat to any profitable business in the country. In an interview with ''The Telegraph'', Deripaska said he was one of the few who worked to clean up Russian industry and provided support to law enforcement agencies. However, in this early chaotic period paying protection money to criminal gangs was inescapable, as revealed in court testimony.{{Cite web|title=Oleg Deripaska: Why I paid crime gangs for protection| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/industry/mining/9218657/Oleg-Deripaska-Why-I-paid-crime-gangs-for-protection.html|work=The Telegraph |accessdate=13 January 2016}} In September 2012, Cherney terminated his UK lawsuit against Deripaska.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10000872396390444549204578022433469797910 |title=Suit Against Russian Billionaire Is Dropped|work=The Wall Street Journal|first1=Paul|last1=Sonne|first2=Alexander|last2=Kolyandr|date=27 September 2012|accessdate=7 November 2012}} === U.S. investigation=== In 2015, Deripaska filed a lawsuit against [[Morgan Stanley]], accusing the bank of using [[insider information]] to [[short (finance)|short sell]] the businessman's $1.5 billion investment in shares of Magma in 2008.{{Cite web|title=Morgan Stanley to face Russian tycoon's insider trading claims |url= http://in.reuters.com/article/morgan-stanley-trial-idINL1N12S3RO20151101|website=Reuters India|accessdate=13 January 2016}} In 2007, Deripaska's Veleron [[investment vehicle]] acquired stock in Canadian based [[Magna International]] through a $1.2 billion loan from [[BNP Paribas]], with Magna shares serving as [[collateral (finance)|collateral]].{{Cite web|title=Russian tycoon Oleg Deripaska sues Morgan Stanley|url=https://www.rt.com/business/320611-deripaska-rusal-bank-court/|website=RT International|accessdate=13 January 2016}} Morgan Stanley was involved in the deal through a swap agreement with BNP Paribas where the US bank assumed the risks of the loan in return for a fixed payment from Paribas.{{Cite web|title=Morgan Stanley Defeats Russian Tycoon’s Short-Selling Claims|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-11-13/morgan-stanley-defeats-russian-tycoon-s-short-selling-claims-igy8py53|website=Bloomberg.com|accessdate=13 January 2016|first=Bob|last=Van Voris|first2=Erik|last2=Larson}} In September 2008, Magna's stocks plummeted, hit by the global economic downturn. BNP issued a $93 million [[margin call]] to Veleron. Morgan Stanley, in turn, learned that Veleron was unlikely to meet the call and sold the stock short.{{Cite news|title=UPDATE 1-Morgan Stanley cleared in Russian tycoon's insider trading lawsuit|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/morgan-stanley-trial-idUSL1N1382UF20151113|newspaper=Reuters|date=13 November 2015|accessdate=13 January 2016}} Deripaska claimed that Morgan Stanley abused its duties and engaged in unlawful [[insider trading]] that resulted in significant financial damage to Veleron, estimated at $15 million to $25 million. A New York jury determined in November 2015 that Morgan Stanley had "acquired inside information and traded on it despite a duty to keep it confidential and not trade on it," finding as well that Morgan Stanley did not have the intent to [[defraud]] Veleron. Veleron strongly disagreed with and said it would file an appeal.{{when|date=June 2016}} In July 2006, whilst Deripaska was involved in a bid to buy the [[Daimler Chrysler]] Group, it was reported that the United States canceled his entry visa; the unnamed official declined to give a reason for the revoking of the visa. The ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' reported that it could have been because Deripaska has been accused of having links to organized crime in Russia and cited as their sources two unnamed U.S. law enforcement officials.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN1143738620070511|title=U.S. revoked Deripaska visa – State Dep't official|first=Jim|last=Wolf|date=11 May 2007|agency=Reuters}} ''The New York Times'' reported on 27 August 2018 that the visa had been revoked on concerns Deripaska might attempt to launder money through real estate transactions.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/27/us/politics/bruce-ohr-trump-justice-department.html|title=Bruce Ohr Fought Russian Organized Crime. Now He’s a Target of Trump.|publisher=|accessdate=29 August 2018}} Deripaska had received a multiple-entry visa in 2005; a U.S. [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] spokesman refused to comment. Lobbying on his behalf had been done by former Senate Republican leader and 1996 presidential candidate [[Bob Dole]] and his Alston & Bird law partners, Senate records show. Alston & Bird was paid about US$260,000 in 2005 for work on "Department of State visa policies and procedures" tied to Deripaska. In 2009, Deripaska was again allowed entry and visited the United States twice. ''The Wall Street Journal'' reported that according to two unnamed FBI administration officials, Deripaska had met with agents regarding a continuing criminal probe, the details of the probe were not known or reported. During Deripaska's visits, he met with leading management figures from investment banks [[Goldman Sachs]] and [[Morgan Stanley]]. The Aluminum company that Deripaska heads, [[United Company RUSAL]], was in preparations for an initial public offering. The easing of Deripaska's visa issues which were an issue for possible investors helped to reassure bankers. The State Department has never said why it revoked his visa and refused to comment on his 2009 visits. The visits were arranged outside of the usual process as the U.S. continues to have concerns about Deripaska's business associations. Deripaska has repeatedly denied a connection to any organized crime and said business rivals have caused the visa to be revoked by smearing him. When interviewed by the BBC in July 2009, Deripaska said that the authorities in the United States had been attempting to blackmail him by revoking his visa and thus affecting possible investors in a negative way and thereby hoping to push Deripaska into cooperating with them.{{cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB125687000832717809 | work=The Wall Street Journal | title=Deripaska Accused Spanish police to answer questions in relation to a money-laundering enquiry.{{cite web|url=http://www.elmundo.es/papel/2010/03/21/mercados/23228430.html |title=Quiosco, El Mundo en ORBYT |work=El Deripaska's business relations with Sergei Popov and Anton Malevsky, alleged heads of Russian organized crime groups.{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/70a1c458-09ff-11df-8b23-00144feabdc0.html?nclick_check=1 |title=/ Comment / Analysis – Rusal: A lingering heat |work=Financial Times |date=25 January 2010 |accessdate=14 May 2011}} Deripaska has accused Michael Chernoy of using Malevsky and the [[Izmaylovskaya gang|Izmailovskaya syndicate]] to extort US$250 million from him as part of a protection racket.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/clash-of-the-oligarchs-1753022.html|title=Clash of the oligarchs|work=The Independent|location=UK|date=20 July 2009|accessdate=14 May 2011|first=Donald|last=MacIntyre}} However, Deripaska has himself been accused of having similar links to Malevsky, who, with his brother Andrei, owned a 10% stake in Deripaska's company. Deripaska denies the claims.Swinford, Steven, "Peter Mandelson oligarch Oleg Deripaska linked to mafia boss", ''The Sunday Times'' (London), 26 October 2008. In November 2011, Spain's High Court sent the criminal cases against Deripaska to the Russian General Prosecutor's office because the root of the cases is Russian.{{cite news|url=http://en.gazeta.ru/news/2011/11/25/a_3848274.shtml|title=Russian Tycoon Deripaska's case given to Russia's court by Spain|publisher=gazeta.ru|first=Darya|last=Ispolnova|date=25 November 2011|accessdate=28 November 2011}} ===Political relationships=== [[File:Vladimir Putin 19 March 2002-4.jpg|thumb|[[Vladimir Putin]] and Deripaska, 19 March 2002]] ====Vladimir Putin==== Deripaska is noted for his close ties with Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]]. Their relationship was visibly strained amidst Deripaska's financial struggles in 2009, but in a widely broadcast incident on Russian television, Putin visited a stalled cement factory owned by Deripaska and berated its management. He forced Deripaska to sign a contract promising to pay nearly $1 million in unpaid wages.{{cite news|last1=Oliphant|first1=Roland|title=Fifteen years of Vladimir Putin: in quotes|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/vladimir-putin/11588182/Fifteen-years-of-Vladimir-Putin-in-quotes.html|accessdate=25 May 2017|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=7 May 2015|language=en}}
{{cite news|last1=Reynolds|first1=Leda|title=ISIS beware: THIS is how hardman Russian President Vladimir Putin gets things DONE|url= http://www.express.co.uk/news/world/610552/ISIS-beware-THIS-is-how-hardman-Vladimir-Putin-gets-things-DONE|accessdate=25 May 2017|work=The Express| date=7 October 2015|language=en}} Their relationship recovered, however, and Deripaska has been described as "Putin's favorite [[Business magnate|industrialist]]".{{cite news|last1=Marcin|first1=Tim|title=Meet Oleg Deripaska, who allegedly worked with former Trump aide Paul Manafort to push Putin's views| url=http://www.newsweek.com/who-oleg-deripaska-paul-manafort-russian-putin-572157|accessdate=25 May 2017|work=Newsweek|date=22 March 2017|language=en}} [[United States diplomatic cables leak|Leaked U.S. diplomatic cables]] from 2006 described Deripaska as "among the 2-3 oligarchs Putin turns to on a regular basis" and "a more-or-less permanent fixture on Putin's trips abroad".{{cite news|last1= Horowitz| first1=Jeff|last2=Day|first2=Chad|title=AP findings on Trump associate's work for Russian oligarch|url=https://apnews.com/ba0027b4c29a4863b096d7216ee0ca58/ap-findings-trump-associates-work-russian-oligarch|accessdate=25 May 2017|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=22 March 2017}} In an interview with ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', Tye Burt, who knows Deripaska and is the CEO of [[Kinross Gold]] said that, "I believe Russia recognizes Oleg's major role in building a renewed economic base in a broad range of domestic businesses and rejuvenating ailing companies and infrastructure." ====Nathaniel Rothschild and Peter Mandelson==== Deripaska is a friend of [[Nathaniel Philip Rothschild|Nathaniel Rothschild]], a major investor in both [[Glencore]] and [[United Company RUSAL]]. Together Deripaska and Rothschild hosted [[George Osborne]] and [[Peter Mandelson]] on Deripaska's yacht in [[Corfu]] in the summer of 2008. {{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/leading-articles/leading-article-the-flawed-judgement-of-a-shadow-chancellor-968549.html|title=Leading article: The flawed judgement of a shadow Chancellor|date=22 October 2008|work=The Independent|location=UK|accessdate=23 November 2009}} Osborne was then Shadow [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] of the United Kingdom and a friend of Rothschild from school and university. It was reported that [[Peter Mandelson]] had maintained private contacts over several years with Oleg Deripaska{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article4982163.ece|title=Lord Mandelson and Oleg Deripaska dined together 'a year before they met'|last=Robertson|first=David|date=21 October 2008|newspaper=The Times|location=UK|accessdate=23 October 2008}} News of the contacts sparked criticism because, as European Union Trade Commissioner, Mandelson had been responsible for decision to cut aluminium tariffs from 6 to 3%, a decision that had benefited Deripaska's Company [[RusAl]].{{cite news|url= http://www.moscowtimes.ru/article/1010/42/371829.htm|title=UK Conservatives Linked to Deripaska|date=22 October 2008|newspaper=[[The Moscow Times]] |accessdate= 23 October 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081126051311/http://www.moscowtimes.ru/article/1010/42/371829.htm|archivedate=26 November 2008}} Mandelson insisted that he had never discussed aluminium tariffs with Deripaska.{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article4932191.ece|title=Peter Mandelson dogged by his links to Russian oligarch|date=13 October 2008|newspaper=The Times|last2=Charter|first2=David|location=UK|accessdate=23 October 2008|first1=David|last1=Robertson}} On 26 October 2008 the [[Shadow Foreign Secretary]] [[William Hague]] claimed the "whole country" wanted "transparency" about Mandelson's previous meetings with Deripaska. In response, Prime Minister [[Gordon Brown]] said Mandelson's dealings with Deripaska had been "found to be above board".{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7691678.stm|title=Tories seek Mandelson 'clarity'|date=26 October 2008|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=30 October 2008}} Mandelson said that meeting business figures from "across the range" in emerging economies was part of his brief as EU Trade Commissioner.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2008/oct/28/peter-mandelson-oleg-deripaska-corfu|title=Mandelson silent on Deripaska|last=Parfitt|first=Tom|date=28 October 2008|newspaper=The Guardian|location=UK|accessdate=30 October 2008}} On 29 October 2008, while Mandelson was on a ministerial visit to Moscow,{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2008/oct/29/russia-mandelson|title=Mandelson hails thaw in relations with Moscow|last=Parfitt|first=Tom|date=29 October 2008|work =The Guardian|location=UK|accessdate=30 October 2008}} it was alleged in the British press that [[Valery Pechyonkin|Valery Pechenkin]], the head of security at Deripaska's company Basic Element, had news|url=https://www.apnews.com/122ae0b5848345faa88108a03de40c5a/Manafort's-plan-to-'greatly-benefit-the-Putin-Government|title=Trump campaign chief linked to Putin interests|last=HORWITZ and
